search_result.title: 55 things to do this summer
search_result.text:
Shane Nyman

USA TODAY NETWORK-Wisconsin

Summer — that magical time of year that takes an eternity to arrive and then bolts in an instant — unofficially begins with Memorial Day weekend.

There's a lot to do and only so many days to fit in all in. To help out, we've gathered up a list of 55 special events (or recurring ones) worthy of your summer to-do list for east-central and northeast Wisconsin. For obvious reasons, we couldn't hit on everything — there's a lot of fun to be had in the months ahead in communities all over the map. But this is a good start to plotting out your summer adventures.

Now get out there and enjoy the season. Before you know it, the last swig of Octoberfest beer will be gone.

1. Stock car races

Ongoing: Race tracks from Manitowoc to Shawano will be roaring all summer long, including at the Wisconsin International Raceway in Kaukauna, a popular Thursday night destination for locals and out-of-towners alike. Among the highlights of the WIR stock car racing schedule are the Red (June 11), White (July 16) and Blue (Aug.13) State Championship Series races and the Eve of Destruction on Sept. 11. Details at wirmotorsports.com.

2. Wisconsin Timber Rattlers

Ongoing: If there's a positive to take from the downer year the Milwaukee Brewers are having, it's the importance that's put on the organization's prospects. The Wisconsin Timber Rattlers have been a launching point for several Brewers (Scooter Gennett, Khris Davis and Wily Peralta among them) as a Class A affiliate and have 45 games at Fox Cities Stadium in Grand Chute remaining this year. Details at timberrattlers.com.

3. Green Bay Botanical Garden Fair

May 29-31: The Green Bay Botanical Garden hosts its annual three-day Garden Fair with more than 100 vendors of plants, garden art and other gardening supplies, plus live music, gardening experts and more May 29-31 weekend. Nationally-known expert, TV personality and author Melinda Myers will be a part of the weekend. Details at gbbg.org.

4. Water ski shows

June 2: Two teams of talented daredevils take to the water in the Fox Cities, providing free entertainment twice a week through August. The Waterboard Warriors season begins at 7 p.m. June 2 at Mueller Park in Wrightstown and continues on Tuesdays and Thursdays. The Webfooters start at 6 p.m. June 3 at Plank Stadium on Wolf River Drive in Fremont and perform Sundays and Wednesdays. Don't try it at home, kids. Details at waterboardwarriors.org and webfooters.org.

5. Outdoor farm markets

June 3: Come at the right time and fresh fruits, vegetables, arts and crafts and other wares line the streets of many communities around east-central Wisconsin. Among them is the sprawling Downtown Appleton Farm Market, which takes over College Avenue 8 a.m.-12:30 p.m. Saturdays from June 20 through Oct. 31. Downtown Appleton's Midweek Farm Market moves to Houdini Plaza this year from 2 to 6 p.m. Wednesdays beginning June 3 and running through Sept. 30. In Green Bay, the farmers market begins May 30 on S. Washington Street from Walnut to Stuart and runs through Oct. 31. It's open 7 a.m. to noon.

6. Heid Music Summer Concert Series

June 4: The weekend feeling comes a little early in June, July and August thanks to the weekly Thursday night concert series in downtown Appleton. This year's slate of 13 performances starts June 4 and rolls on through Aug. 27, with shows at Houdini Plaza and, on the third Thursday of each month, Jones Park. This year marks the 10th anniversary and among the highlights is a July 16 show featuring Vic Ferrari's Symphony on the Rocks. The Aug. 6 date also is set aside as a Mile of Music showcase. Other performers include Boxkar, Road Trip, Cool Waters Band and Unity the Band. The concerts are free and run 5:30-8:30 p.m. Details at appletondowntown.org.

7. De Pere EastWest Fest

June 5: More than 60 artists will take part in an inaugural music festival in De Pere that's spread out over six Friday nights in June, July and August. Both sides of the Fox River will be involved, with more than 70 shows in all. The talent includes Swear and Shake, Boom Forest and Motherfolk. Performance nights are June 5 and 19, July 10 and 24 and Aug. 7 and 21. All shows are free except a June 5 concert with Cory Chisel and Adriel Denae at Dudley Birder Hall on the St. Norbert campus. Details at definitelydepere.org.

8. Great Wisconsin Cheese Festival

June 5-7: This annual festival in Little Chute's Doyle Park is about as Wisconsin as it gets. The three-day celebration boasts live music from Vic Ferrari, Unity the Band, Andy Grammer and Cash Cash (among others), plus a cheese curd eating contest, a wine tasting, amusement rides, magic and comedy shows, cheese carving and plenty more. Details at littlechutewi.org.

9. Eagles at the Resch Center

June 7: The Rock and Roll Hall of Famers bring "The History of the Eagles" tour to the Resch Center in Ashwaubenon. It's the third stop at the arena for one of rock's most successful acts and the show features classics spanning the band's career. Tickets, on sale through Ticket Star, start at $89 and climb all the way up to $950 for the most elaborate VIP package.

10. Steel Bridge Songfest

June 11-14: What began a decade ago as a campaign to restore a historic bridge in Sturgeon Bay has turned into an extensive annual celebration of original songwriting. The performances cover four days and three nights in more than a dozen venues in Sturgeon Bay's downtown and more than 200 artists are involved, from as close to home as Green Bay, Appleton and Fond du Lac and as far away as Arizona, California and Washington. Four-day general admission passes are $25. Details at steelbridgesongfest.org.

11. Walleye Weekend

June 12-14: Walleye Weekend draws big crowds to Fond du Lac for a three-day party that's about much more than fishing. There's a lengthy list of musical acts, including cover bands, tribute acts and original artists. There's a boat exhibit, fireworks, motorcycle ride, Familyland activities, a Sunday Mass and, of course, a fishing tournament. New this year is a wine bar. Details at fdlfest.com.

12. Neenah Streetball

June 13: This year's version of the annual three-on-three hoops tournament that takes over the streets of downtown Neenah is packed into one day. The June 13 action features divisions ranging from elementary school-aged children to players with college experience. Beyond the games, there are a variety of skills competitions, including a free throw contest for children age 7 and younger. Those lacking in basketball skills can still enjoy the festive atmosphere. Details at streetball3on3.org.

13. Flag Day Parade

June 13: This marks the 65th year a parade will honor Old Glory in downtown Appleton around Flag Day. The parade, which this year will highlight the U.S. Navy, gets rolling (and marching!) at 2 p.m. on the corner of Wisconsin Avenue and Oneida Street and finishing up at College Avenue and Drew Street. A free post-parade party with live music starts at 5 p.m. at Don Hawkins baseball field on the grounds of the Appleton American Legion on College Avenue. Details at appleton.org.

14. Electric City Experience

June 13: Kaukauna toasts the 225th anniversary of its permanent settlement with 225 activities and performances over the course of one Saturday in June. The day begins at noon and will feature live music from Christopher Gold, Red Light Saints, the Electra Color and loads of other Fox Valley bands, a vendor market, children's activities and inflatables and more. The celebration is topped off in Central Park, where Cory Chisel will perform a free concert at 7:30 p.m. Details at Electric City Experience on Facebook.

15. Jordy Nelson Charity Softball Game

June 14: The annual charity softball game between players from the Green Bay Packers' offense and defense is back at Fox Cities Stadium in Grand Chute. The action starts at 1:05 p.m. and will also feature a game between Packers players and sponsors and a home run derby. The only remaining tickets, which are available at timberrattlers.com, are the $12 grass seating option. Last year the offense smashed the defense by a count of 26-11 in front of more than 7,000 fans. Details at timberrattlers.com.

16. Juneteenth Celebration

June 14: This year marks the sixth year for Appleton's Juneteenth Celebration, a remembrance of the end of slavery in the United States that celebrates freedom, unity and community. The City of Appleton and African Heritage Inc. partner to make the noon-6 p.m. event happen in Unity Park, with live music, entertainment, food vendors and activities for all ages. Details at appleton.org.

17. Waterfest

June 18: The annual concert series held at the Leach Amphitheater in Oshkosh returns for another year with a diverse lineup of headlining acts. Pablo Cruise (June 18), Rusted Root (June 25), Smash Mouth (July 9), Lake Street Dive (July 16), Todd Rundgren (Aug. 6) and the Fray (Aug. 7) are among this year's 10 bill-toppers. Ticket prices vary by performance. VIP season passes are $100 before May 31 and $125 after. Details at waterfest.org.

18. Mackville Nationals

June 19-21: St. Edward Parish in Mackville, located three miles north of Appleton on State 47, draws big rigs from around the Midwest for the annual weekend of truck and tractor pulls. The three-day event also boasts amusement park rides, a Saturday morning pancake and porkie breakfast, a children's Dash for Cash, live music and more. Details at mackvillenationals.com.

19. Metro Jam

June 19-20: Washington Park in downtown Manitowoc is home to the 37th annual Metro Jam in June. Though the complete performance lineup is yet to be revealed, we do know that the Black Crowes co-founder Rich Robinson will headline June 20. The free show is at 8:30 p.m. We'll have to hang tight for the rest of the performers, which have been a diverse mix in recent years. Details at metrojam.org.

20. Kenny Chesney and Jason Aldean at Lambeau

June 20: Kenny Chesney's return to Lambeau Field in Green Bay is no retread, in part because the followup to his 2011 concert at the home of the Packers includes a big-time co-headliner in Jason Aldean. The two country superstars aligned their tours for 10 stadium stops and the Lambeau visit has the makings for east-central Wisconsin's biggest concert event of the year. Brantley Gilbert and Cole Swindell round out the bill for the show that's expected to draw more than 50,000 people. Tickets start at $41 and are on sale through Ticketmaster.

21. Aurora BayCare Toughman Wisconsin

June 20: The epic fitness event formerly known as the High Cliff Triathlon celebrates year No. 12 with hundreds of participants pushing their bodies to the limit. Held at High Cliff State Park with a course that both overlooks and dives right into Lake Winnebago, the main event is a 1.2-mile swim, 56-mile bike and 13.1-mile run. The sprint version is a ¼-mile swim, 22-mile bike and 5K run. Details at dutrirun.com.

22. Country USA

June 23-27: The annual bash at Ford Festival Park in Oshkosh celebrates its 20th year with as potent a lineup as ever. Tim McGraw, Eric Church, Lee Brice, Eli Young Band and Miranda Lambert are the headliners for the five-day country music bonanza that features 25 acts in all. Five-day general admission tickets are $200 at the gate. Camping passes are sold out. Details at countryusaoshkosh.com.

23. Chickenfest

June 25-27: Darboy Community Park is home to the annual Chickenfest during the last weekend in June, with a load of Fox Valley bands performing over the course of three days. Carnival rides, food, beer sampling, chicken dance competitions and fireworks are part of the fun. The second annual Chicken Chase 5K Run/Walk gets moving at 9 a.m. June 27 and a parade is set for 11 a.m. Details at darboychickenfest.com.

24. Edge the Ledge

June 28: The fifth annual Edge the Ledge, a 5K obstacle course for teams and individuals, takes place at Fondy Sports Park in Fond du Lac. The challenge, which sports a pirate theme for 2015, invites participants to climb, crawl, jump, swim and conquer — and maybe get a little muddy. A costume contest starts the day at 6:45 a.m. and the race begins at 7. Adults can register before June 24 for $50, pairs for $45 each, teams of six or more for $40 each and kids $15. Prices (except for kids) go up from June 24 to the day of the event. Details at dutrirun.com.

25. Sawdust Days

July 1-5: Crowds of more than 150,000 people are expected to pour into Menominee Park for the annual multi-cultural celebration on the shores of Lake Winnebago in Oshkosh. The name is a nod to the 1870s, when Oshkosh was home to 24 sawmills, 15 shingle mills and seven sash and door factories and was dubbed "Sawdust City." Four stages of music, carnival rides, fireworks, a historic village and a 5K are among the attractions. Details at sawdustdays.com.

26. Mid-Western Rodeo

July 2-4: Back for another year in Manawa is the Mid-Western Rodeo during the busy Fourth of July weekend. Performances are 7:30 p.m. July 2 and 3 and 2 and 7:30 p.m. July 4 and a parade, fireworks and live music regularly are added to the slate of roping and riding. Details at manawarodeo.org.

27. Fourth of July celebrations

July 3-4: America's going to be another year older come July 4, so you better believe people are going to gather in public spaces and take in some fireworks. As a bonus, the holiday lands on a Saturday this year. Communities all over east-central Wisconsin will host celebrations, including Green Bay's Fire Over the Fox (July 4), Appleton's Memorial Park (July 3), Communityfest at Neenah's Riverside Park and Menasha's Jefferson Park (July 3-4), Sheboygan's Big Bang Festival (July 4), Lakeside Park in Fond du Lac (July 4) and Manitowoc picnic and fireworks (July 4).

28. Polkafest

July 3-5: This ain't your grandkids' dance music. The Altrusa Club of Appleton puts on their yearly Polkafest at Romy's Nitingale in Black Creek with back-to-back-to-back days of polka for a good cause. The event, which features the Sugarbush Boys, Gordy Prochaska's Little Fishermen, Gary's Ridgeland Dutchmen and Hauser's Hotshots, is a fundraiser for Homeless Connections and other Altrusa service projects. Tickets are available at the door. Details at appletonaltrusa.com.

29. Lifest

July 9-12: Oshkosh is nicknamed "Event City" thanks in part to the slew of summer festivals it hosts each year. One of these events is Lifest, a festival at the Sunnyview Expo Center with big-name performers from the Christian music world, comedians, speakers and more. The lineup features Newsboys, Skillet, Matthew West, Tenth Avenue North and Matt Maher. The weekend also has a 5K fun run, sports tournaments, inflatable games, a kids zone and more. Details at lifest.com.

30. Iola Old Car Show and Swap Meet

July 9-11: The Iola Old Car Show is one of the biggest annual events for auto enthusiasts in the Midwest and this year is no different. With more than 2,200 show cars, 4,400 swap spaces, 1,000 car corral displays and 1,600 camp sites, the three-day event draws big crowds to the small community in Waupaca County. Details at iolaoldcarshow.com.

31. Greenville Catfish Extravaganza

July 10-11: The Greenville Lions put on their family friendly community night on July 10 at Greenville Lions Park with a fun run, catfish races, live music, games and more. The next night belongs to country vets Alabama, who headline the July 11 Catfish Concert with the Kentucky Headhunters and Grand Union. Tickets for the concert are $35 in advance and $45 at the gate. Details at greenvillelions.org.

32. County fairs

July 15: A Wisconsin summer just doesn't feel complete without a trip to a county fair. There are plenty to pick from and all offer up carnival rides, plenty of games, live music and other forms of live entertainment – think tractor pulls, monster trucks and the like – and 4-H animal and craft exhibits. As for the big concerts, the Outagamie County Fair runs July 21-26 in Seymour and features Seether, Aaron Tippin and the Cadillac Three. The Fond du Lac County Fair is July 15-19 and has Grand Funk Railroad, Great White, Slaughter and Montgomery Gentry booked. Other county fairs continue into early September. Check fair websites for details.

33. Rock USA

July 15-18: Ford Festival Park in Oshkosh becomes a heavy metal haven for four days in July with the return of Rock USA. Alice Cooper, Judas Priest, Avenged Sevenfold and Def Leppard highlight the lineup of 20 acts that span decades of hard rock. Four-day general admission tickets are $159 at the gate. Details at rockusaoshkosh.com.

34. Paperfest

July 17-19: Kimberly's annual free family festival packs Sunset Park for three days in July and raises money for nonprofit and civic organizations in the Fox Valley. Dead Horses, Road Trip, Seasaw, Hugh Robert Masterson, the Traveling Suitcase and Kyle Megna and the Monsoons are among the more than two dozen entertainment offerings. There's also a car show, a 5K, three-on-three hoops and a fishing tournament. Details at paperfest.com.

35. Bergstrom-Mahler Museum of Glass Arts Festival

July 19: The 41st annual arts festival to benefit the Bergstrom-Mahler Museum of Glass will be held from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. July 19 in Neenah's Riverside Park. The day features art, of course, along with food, children's activities, live bands and a beer and wine garden. The park is located across the street from the museum. Details at bmmglass.com.

36. Appleton Children's Parade

July 22: College Avenue will peak in cuteness during the seventh annual Downtown Appleton Children's Parade, which benefits the Building for Kids Children's Museum. It will roll, run, walk, jump and skip along College Avenue for children ages 12 and younger. Check-in is at 5:15 p.m. at Houdini Plaza and the line gets moving at 6. A family party starts at 6:30 p.m. in City Park with food, beverages and entertainment. Prizes will be handed out for a variety of categories, including imagination, creativity, best float and best group. Details at buildingforkids.org.

37. Art at the Park

July 26: Tens of thousands of visitors will descend on historic City Park in Appleton for the 55th annual Art at the Park, showcasing upwards of 200 artists from around the country. The free event runs 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. and also features live music, food vendors, children's activities and more. Details at troutmuseum.org.

38. EAA AirVenture

July 20-26: There are few events in a Fox Valley summer that compare in size and scope to the annual gathering of aviation buffs in Oshkosh. Dierks Bentley headlines the opening day concert and what follows are several days of air shows, music, movies, a 5K run/walk and more. Members of Apollo 13 will be on hand for a 45th anniversary celebration and Gary Sinise (who starred in the 1995 film "Apollo 13") will be back with his Lt. Dan Band. Daily admission is $45 ($24 for students ages 6-18 and free for ages 5 and younger). Details at eaa.org.

39. Packers training camp

July 30: If there's a positive to be found with giving any attention to the coming fall, it's the arrival of another NFL season. The Green Bay Packers begin their quest to wipe the end of the 2014 season from memory with the opening of training camp on July 30. The schedule for the open practices should be arriving soon, allowing cheeseheads the opportunity plot out their first glimpses of Aaron Rodgers & Co. A bit later, Lambeau Field will host preseason visits from the Eagles (Aug. 29) and Saints (Sept. 3) before the regular season kicks off Sept. 13 at Soldier Field in Chicago. Details at packersnews.com.

40. Johnsonville Brat Days

July 30-Aug. 1: Because of course somewhere in Wisconsin there's a festival named after brats. Sheboygan is that somewhere, with the Jaycees putting on an annual celebration in Kiwanis Park that includes a brat-eating contest, live music, a brat trot, a parade and all the meaty and frothy eats that make up a good community party. Details at brat-days.com.

41. Feast with the Beasts

Aug. 3: There are a number of great times to visit the NEW Zoo in Suamico, but the 16th annual Feast With the Beasts fundraiser is one worth highlighting. The event is an opportunity to dine out at the zoo and take in all the sights. Tickets are $35 in advance and $40 at the door. Details at newzoo.org.

42. Mile of Music

Aug. 6-9: The third annual Mile of Music festival returns to downtown Appleton with about 175 artists performing about 800 shows in about 65 venues, including Jones Park, Houdini Plaza and the Lawrence Memorial Chapel. Like previous years, the four-day event focuses on original songwriting and leans on the folk, Americana and indie rock genres. Among the performers are the Milk Carton Kids and Cory Chisel and the Wandering Sons. A majority of the performances are free. Details at mileofmusic.com.

43. Hamburger Fest

Aug. 7-9: Nobody celebrates slabs of beef quite like Seymour. This year's helping of the annual Hamburger Festival is centered around the theme of "Charlie and His Hamburger Factory," named for Charles Nagreen, who is believed to have coined the term hamburger in 1885. The three-day festival features a burger-eating contest, the serving of a 190-pound cheeseburger, hot air balloons, live music and more. Details at homeofthehamburger.org.

44. Ganther Race the Lake

Aug. 16: What better way to spend an August day than a 90-mile bike ride? Ganther Race the Lake takes off at 5:45 a.m. with bikers pedaling their way around Lake Winnebago and all its scenic glory. The course begins on Scott Street in Fond du Lac, travels up the west side of the lake through Appleton to the half-way point at High Cliff State Park. The home stretch heads down the east side of the lake and finishes at Lakeside Park in Fond du Lac. The trek is open to individuals and relay groups. Details at dutrirun.com.

45. Artstreet

Aug. 28-30: The artwork of 200 artists will be showcased for the 34th year for what is one of Green Bay's most popular downtown events. Big crowds will gather and gawk at paintings, glasswork, photography, ceramics, jewelry, you name it, with street performers, live music, lots of food and other goodies stuffed into the weekend. Admission is free. Details at mosaicartsinc.org.

46. Fox Jazz Fest

Sept. 5-6: The 22nd annual Fox Jazz Fest brings two days of free music to Jefferson Park in Menasha over Labor Day weekend. The 2015 lineup is yet to be announced, but if past years are an indication, expect a heavy hitter or two from the jazz world to be involved. You also can expect a slate of local, regional and national artists to go along with food and beverages to help smooth the transition into fall. Details at foxjazzfest.com.

47. PGA Championship

Aug. 13-16: One of professional golf's major tournaments returns to Whistling Straits in Kohler in August for the third time, putting the course on the rugged terrain along the Lake Michigan shoreline north of Sheboygan at the center of the sports world. Many of the game's best players (and biggest names) will duke it out in hopes of joining Vijay Singh and Martin Kaymer as PGA Championship conquerors of Whistling Straits. Details at americanclubresort.com/golf/whistling-straits.

48. NASCAR Xfinity Series at Road America

Aug. 27-29: As usual, Road America at Elkhart Lake has a stacked summer season. One key event to circle on the schedule is the weekend of Aug. 27-31, when the NASCAR Xfinity Series rumbles into town for the Road America 180 Fire Up by Johnsonville. Race fans can catch some of NASCAR's future stars on the four-mile, 14-turn road circuit. Details at roadamerica.com.

49. Rock for Autism

Aug. 29: This year's rendition of Rock for Autism, an annual fund-raising concert to support children with autism, is set at the Leach Amphitheater in Oshkosh and will be headlined by former Ratt lead singer Stephen Pearcy. Also on the bill are Fox Valley bands Red Light Saints, Sonic Circus, Daphni, Sedated and Eminence. Tickets are $15 and available at rockforautism.net and at Festival Foods locations around the Fox Valley.

50. Kites Over Lake Michigan

Sept. 5-6: For a ninth year, it's flying objects galore in the skies of Two Rivers, home of the largest kite festival in the Midwest. The free Labor Day weekend event features huge show kites over Lake Michigan, banners along the beach, kite demos, children's events and a nighttime kite fly with lanterns. Details at manitowoc.info.

51. Fondue Fest

Sept. 12: The food-based summer festivals continue into September with Fond du Lac hosting its ninth annual Fondue Fest from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Sept. 12. It's an opportunity to dip into a day of live music, kids activities and, of course, upwards of 90 pounds of melted cheese. The day's fondue offerings are prepared by the Moraine Park Technical College culinary arts program. Details at fonduefest.com.

52. Quarry Quest

Sept. 12: The annual earth-moving family experience at Michels Materials Quarry on Tullar Road in Neenah is set for 9 a.m.-4 p.m. Sept. 12. The event draws crowds in the thousands each year with children getting the opportunity to strap on a hardhat and participate in truckloads of interactive activities, including sand-sculpting, brick-laying, a jewelry jamboree and more. Tickets are $7 adults and $5 youth in advance and $10 adults and $8 youth at the gate. Details at quarryquest.com.

53. Tough Mudder

Sept. 12-13: Road America is no stranger to intense competition, but come September it'll be men and women only figuratively putting the pedal to the floor on a rugged course. The Tough Mudder is one of the hottest trends in fitness and comes to Elkhart Lake looking to draw participants from around the state to run, jump, climb, splash and maybe shock themselves in the name of a good time — and for the refreshing beer after the race. Details at toughmudder.com.

54. Community First Fox Cities Marathon

Sept. 18-20: Appleton's big marathon weekend is highlighted by Sunday's 26.2- and 13.1-mile slogs, but there's also a Friday kids fun run, a two-day health and wellness expo and a Saturday 5K run/walk to help get folks of all ages and abilities involved. The 25th annual marathon, which has a new course this year highlighting trails, waterfronts and parks, begins at the University of Wisconsin-Fox Valley in Menasha and weaves through six Fox Cities communities before finishing at Riverside Park in Neenah. Details at foxcitiesmarathon.org.

55. Octoberfest

Sept. 25-26: The epic block party that is Octoberfest is one of the staples of the annual Appleton entertainment calendar. This year's weekend bash is Sept. 25 and 26, with License to Cruise highlighting the Friday night festivities and then the day of drinks, food, live music and more (including herds and herds of patrons) taking up the 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. stretch of Saturday. The only downside? It's often looked at as the unofficial farewell to summer. Details at octoberfestonline.org.

— Shane Nyman: 920-993-1000, ext. 240, snyman@postcrescent.com or on Twitter @shanenyman

search_result.title: Delaware Senate approves annual inspections of long-term care ...
search_result.text:
Senate Bill 215, requiring annual inspections of long-term care facilities, was approved by the state Senate on Tuesday.

The legislation is part of a package of bills aimed at reforming the long-term care industry.

Efforts to improve the state's policing of these facilities were prompted after a 2023 Delaware Online/The News Journal investigation found Delaware has failed to police the industry over the years.

The Delaware Senate on Tuesday unanimously approved a bill that will require annual inspections of long-term care facilities.

Senate Bill 215 is part of a package of bills to reform the long-term care industry and ensure adequate oversight of assisted living and nursing homes providing services to a vulnerable population.

It now goes to the state House of Representatives for consideration.

search_result.title: Merrill Reese, voice of Philadelphia Eagles, going into Hall of Fame
search_result.text:
Merrill Reese, the longtime voice of the Philadelphia Eagles, is heading to the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

Reese, who has been the play-by-play man for the Eagles since 1977, will receive the 2024 Pete Rozelle Radio-Television Award. He will be honored during the 2024 Pro Football Hall of Fame Enshrinement Week, which includes the Class of 2024 Enshrinement on Saturday, Aug. 3, in Tom Benson Hall of Fame Stadium.

“Each year, the Hall of Fame recognizes an individual who has dedicated their career to improving radio and television in professional football, and this year’s recipient, Merrill Reese, represents exactly what we look for when we talk about who’s made a big impact in broadcasting,” Jim Porter, president of the Pro Football Hall of Fame said in a release. “For nearly a half-century, fans tuning into Eagles games, including opposing fans, have had the privilege of hearing Merrill’s legendary voice.”

Eagles news:Jalen Hurts' non-answer on Eagles' Nick Sirianni reveals a real one. It's not a disconnect

Reese began his radio career as a sportscaster for WPAZ in Pottstown, Pennsylvania, calling high school football games. After WPAZ, he worked for WBCB in Levittown, Pennsylvania, where he currently serves as co-owner. In the early 1970s, he worked at different radio stations, doing morning sports on WWDB and pregame and postgame Eagles shows on WIP.

All things Eagles: Latest Philadelphia Eagles news, schedule, roster, stats, injury updates and more.

A lifelong Philadelphia native, Reese attended Temple University.

Throughout his illustrious career, Reese has received numerous awards and recognition, including Pennsylvania Sportscaster of the Year, Lindsey Nelson Award for Excellence in Sportscasting, Philadelphia’s Best Sportscaster by Philadelphia Magazine and induction into the Pennsylvania Sports Hall of Fame, Temple University Communications Hall of Fame and Overbrook High School Hall of Fame.

search_result.title: How has Delaware been impacted by fast-food prices soaring?
search_result.text:
Remember when you were a kid back in 2013 and you had a game or concert after school?

Everything went well and your parents were so proud they decided to take you out to McDonald's for dinner.

Dad ordered a Big Mac meal, you and mom ordered Quarter Pounder with cheese meals and your little sister got a cheeseburger burger Happy Meal. Dad winked and pulled a $20 bill out of his wallet and he got change back.

Those days are gone, replaced by fast-food prices shooting up because of inflation. According to a report in USA TODAY, the Bureau of Labor Statistics' latest reading from the so-called fast-food index saw annual inflation for the sector come in at 4.8%. The BLS also found that prices in "limited-service restaurants" increased by 47% since 2014.

While the prices have shot up, demand for convenient meals has increased. Between 2013 and 2016, 36.6% of adults consumed fast food on a given day, according to a 2018 study by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Market research company Drive Research reported in 2023 that 65% of respondents ate fast food once a week.

With demand up and the post-COVID-19 world being hit by inflation, the cost of a Big Mac, Whopper, Dave's Single and Famous Star burger have risen.

What's the average cost of a signature combo meal?

How fast have fast food prices risen? After years of slight increases, the prices have gone up dramatically.

Recently, USA TODAY surveyed fast-food restaurants' signature meals to find out the average cost. The meals chosen were:

McDonald's Big Mac combo

Wendy's Dave's Single with cheese combo

Burger King's Whopper with cheese combo

Hardee's Famous Star Combo

The results showed McDonald's had the most affordable signature combo at $9.72. Wendy's was second at $10.79, Burger King was third at $10.93 and Hardee's was fourth at $11.68.

Using Internet Archive's Wayback Machine to access fastfoodmenuprices.com website from 2013 moving forward, you can see fast food prices were stagnant until this year.

Over the last year, the price of the signature combos has shot up $3-$4.

What's the average cost of a signature combo meal in Delaware?

While every franchise owner can set its prices, the cost of the signature meals throughout the First State is rather consistent. After looking at the McDonald's, Burger King, Wendy's and Hardee's menus throughout the state, here's what we found:

Delaware's average prices are, for the most part, lower, roughly 90 cents cheaper than the national averages. The only combo that is more expensive is the McDonald's Big Mac combo, which was 28 cents higher than the national average. However, it's still an increase from where the national average was a year ago.

While still more affordable, the prices are almost putting the fast food giants into the same area as restaurants like Applebees, which sells a Classic Cheeseburger with fries in Wilmington for $13.29, or Chili's, which sells an Oldtimer with cheese and fries in Christiana for $12.29.

McDonald's secret menu item:McDonald's Dinner Box may be a secret menu item, but we have a way to find it

Free Chicken McNuggets:When the Phillies win, McDonald's has a deal waiting for you

How does Delaware's prices compare with other cities?

USA TODAY reporters looked at the average cost of the signature combos in several cities throughout the country. Here's a look at how their finding compared to Delaware.

Looking at the prices along the East Coast, Delaware's prices are generally in line with cities within the region. It's cheaper to get a signature meal in Delaware than in New York, but, in other cities, it depends on the restaurant.

A glance across the country shows fast food in the First State is a better value than on the West Coast, but Delaware's prices were higher than Chicago and Houston.

McDonald's, Wendy's and Burger King fight inflation

As previously reported, McDonald's was hit with backlash after the New York Post reported last July that a McDonald's at a Connecticut rest stop was charging $18 for a Big Mac combo meal. In February, McDonald's CEO Chris Kempczinski committed to an affordable menu in 2024.

McDonald's is delivering on that promise with $5 value meals starting June 25. They also have special sharable meals found on its app that provide large quantities of food for a low price. Each restaurant has a shareable menu.

According to a USA TODAY story, Burger King announced its own $5 meal deal set to arrive in June. Wendy's announced a $3 breakfast combo in addition to weekly free chicken nugget deals through the Wendy's app and limited promotions.

search_result.title: 5 poisonous plants to avoid in Delaware this summer
search_result.text:
After a long winter, flowers aren't the only thing blooming in Delaware.

The First State is host to poison ivy, oak and sumac, as well as poison hemlock and the equally poisonous spotted water hemlock, but you shouldn’t let that keep you from enjoying the outdoors.

“It’s really just being aware of your surroundings when out in nature or in areas that are overgrown,” said the University of Delaware Cooperative Extension’s Blake Moore.

Reactions to contact with poisonous plants vary greatly. A mere brush with them will usually result in a rash at worst, but everyone reacts differently, experts say, so it’s important to know how to identify poisonous plants and steer clear.

The most extreme reactions, to include death, usually result from the ingestion of poisonous plants or the inhalation of their toxins.

Poison ivy, oak and sumac

All three of these plants release urushiol, an oil that can cause a rash or even blisters in humans, but poison ivy is likely the only one you’ll ever come across in Delaware.

Poison ivy is common and widespread, and Moore pointed out it’s a native plant with wildlife value. Various birds and mammals feed on the berries.

PLANTS:Smothering vines, burning bushes among invasive plants in Delaware. Try these natives.

“But it’s not something we want around our homes,” he said.

The old saying, “Leaves of three, let it be,” holds true. While some harmless plants also have three leaves, poison ivy’s appearance can be so varied, it’s best to avoid any plant with clusters of three leaves.

“The leaves can be round or serrated. It can grow as a vine, ground cover, up trees. It has that big, long, hairy root that can grow up trees,” said Garret Valencik, the Delaware Department of Agriculture’s noxious weed program manager.

Poison oak and sumac are “documented but uncommon,” Moore said, and are usually seen in only deep woods or wetlands.

ENVIRONMENT:Sussex changes wetland protections amid growth, but exceptions worry environmental groups

Poison oak is a low shrub that shares poison ivy’s three-leaf clusters. Its leaves are fuzzy and lobed with rounded tips, according to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration.

Poison sumac can appear as a low shrub or small tree and is mostly found in wetlands. It has clusters of seven to 13 smooth leaves.

Most pets aren’t sensitive to these plants, according to the FDA, but the oil can stick to their fur and transfer to humans. If your pet comes in contact with poison ivy, oak or sumac, give them a bath with gloves on.

MORE:'No other option': How Millsboro bypass will affect rare, threatened, endangered species

Poison hemlock and spotted water hemlock

Both poison hemlock and spotted water hemlock look similar to the very common Queen Anne’s Lace, or wild carrot.

An easy way to tell them apart: wild carrot has a hairy stem, while hemlock stems are smooth. Both have “small white flowers in umbrella-like groupings,” according to the Department of Agriculture.

“Foragers who eat wild carrot have to be careful, but they usually know what they’re doing,” Valencik said. “They’re toxic to pets, too.”

Poison hemlock is an invasive plant that grows to between 6 and 8 feet tall. The stems can have purple blotches and the leaves are dark glossy green, fernlike, triangular and lacey, according to the Department of Agriculture.

“We’re seeing poison hemlock quite a bit this year,” Valencik said. “It’s widespread throughout the state. It’s usually near water, but it can be found in garden beds if a seed happens to blow in.”

Poison hemlock can also be found in ditches and meadows. It is important to keep it out of areas where livestock feed.

MORE:How Wilmington is trying to leverage the power of trees in its effort to fight crime

Spotted water hemlock is a native plant, almost always found in wetlands or growing along a body of water. It grows up to 6 feet tall, and the stems can be green, purple or both. Its leaves are also lacey and fernlike. Some people say spotted water hemlock has a musty smell, according to Valencik.

Removing poisonous plants

When it comes to your yard, you can always glove up, carefully pull plants from the ground and put them in the trash can.

“It’s always a good idea to wear gloves while weeding,” Valencik said.

If you’re particularly sensitive to poisonous plants, there's no shame in leaving the job to someone else.

INSECTS:Feel something crawling on your back? You don't want it to be one of these 6 bugs.

Herbicide is another option, but plants that grow along bodies of water, like spotted water hemlock, must be removed by a licensed professional using aquatic-approved products.

Do not burn or mow poisonous plants. The toxins will be released into the air and can affect anyone nearby.

If you suspect you’ve found poison or spotted water hemlock, you can take a picture and email it to DDA.Marketing@delaware.gov for identification.

In cases of possible ingestion or inhalation of toxins, call 911 immediately.

search_result.title: What kind of snakes are in Delaware: Guide
search_result.text:
Danger noodles. Nope ropes. Spicy pasta.

Humanity’s primal fear of snakes reigns even in the meme age. They’re slithery, slimy and sneaky and can induce fear in even the bravest of today’s keyboard warriors.

Delaware is home to 19 species of snakes, according to state herpetologist Nate Nazdrowicz, and the truth is, they're mostly harmless.

“Many snakes prey on other species that we would consider pests so it’s beneficial to have them around,” Nazdrowicz said. “Several snakes feed on rodents that might tear up your lawn. Some feed on slugs that will eat your garden plants.”

As part of the food web, they’re also food themselves for species like hawks and owls.

“If you’re not afraid of them, the best thing to do is just leave them be,” Nazdrowicz said.

REPTILES:How 2 Delaware high school seniors are making their mark in turtle conservation

But many people, if not most, are afraid of snakes. If you’re one of them, Nazdrowicz has some recommendations for you.

“Snakes are found in areas that provide food, shelter and areas where they find it easy to regulate their body temperatures. If you have noticed a snake hanging around your house, then your yard is likely providing these resources for the snake,” he said.

To keep snakes out of your yard, make it less attractive to them and the species they eat. Mow frequently and keep flower beds neat. Don’t allow leaves to collect or pile sticks. Don’t feed pets or store birdseed outside. Don’t use rocks in landscaping.

“Snakes are less likely to move through low grass or sparsely vegetated areas because they feel exposed to avian predators,” Nazdrowicz said.

PLANTS:5 poisonous plants to avoid in Delaware this summer, from poison ivy to spotted water hemlock

If you encounter a snake and feel the need to force it to move along, you can do so safely with a garden hose, Nazdrowicz said.

If you're bitten by a snake, try to take a picture of it so it can be positively identified. Bites from Delaware's only venomous snake, the eastern copperhead, are uncommon, according to Nazdrowicz. Death from such bites is even rarer, but if you are bitten by a copperhead, seek medical attention immediately.

Snakes of Delaware

You’ll likely only ever see four of Delaware’s 19 species of snakes; the eastern rat snake, black racer, common garter snake and common watersnake.

The rest are rarely seen, for a variety of reasons. They’re secretive, burrowers, just plain tiny or all of the above.

DELAWARE:How dire is plight of Bethany Beach firefly amid Sussex County development?

Three of them — the plain-bellied watersnake, scarletsnake and red cornsnake — are endangered. Five others are considered critically imperiled, including Delaware’s only venomous snake: the eastern copperhead.

Using some information from the Virginia Herpetological Society, here is a little about each snake and how to identify them. It’s important to keep in mind that juvenile snakes can look vastly different from adults.

SNAKES:Biologists catch record-breaking 215-pound Burmese python in Florida Everglades

Eastern garter snake

The common garter snake is on the small side, growing to about 2.5 feet. Adults are brownish-green with a black checkerboard pattern and usually have a yellowish stripe down their back center. They’re found in a variety of habitats and feed on frogs, fish and slugs.

Black rat snake

As an adult, the eastern black rat snake will grow to be about 5 feet long. It’s black with white on its belly and around its mouth. These skilled climbers eat mainly small warm-blooded animals, such as mice and birds, as well as bird eggs. They live in many different habitats.

When feeling threatened, they may take a striking position and vibrate their tails, like a rattlesnake.

Northern black racer

Black racers and rat snakes are often confused. They are similar in size and color and also live in a variety of habitats, but the racer has smooth scales, while rat snakes’ are more textured. Racers also eat small mammals, as well as frogs and even other snakes. They are very fast, as their name suggests.

Common watersnake

Most common watersnakes grow to about 3 feet long and have black, white and reddish-brown crossbands. As their name suggests, they are usually found near water – mainly freshwater but sometimes brackish. They eat mostly fish and frogs.

Dekay's Brownsnake

DeKay’s brownsnakes are usually only about 1 foot long. They vary in color from gray to brown and have paired black spots. They’re easily confused with garters.

Dekay’s brownsnakes are nocturnal and not often seen. They’re found in a variety of habitats under logs, rocks or other debris, and eat mainly slugs and earthworms.

Plain-bellied watersnake

Plain-bellied watersnakes are brownish with orangey undersides and can reach lengths of 5 feet. Their habitats and diets are similar to those of the common watersnake. They are endangered in Delaware.

Scarletsnake

Endangered scarletsnakes grow to between 14 and 20 inches. Often confused with milksnakes, scarletsnakes have red blotches outlined in black with a cream color in between. They are burrowers, found in sandy, loose soil, usually among pine trees. They eat a variety of small reptiles, mammals and insects, but prefer reptile eggs.

Eastern copperhead

The eastern copperhead is Delaware’s only venomous snake. People confuse all kinds of snakes for copperheads, especially juvenile rat snakes, hog-nosed snakes and watersnakes.

This species has vertical pupils, like a cat. It’s tan in color with hourglass-shaped crossbands of varying shades of brown.

According to Nazdrowicz, copperheads are only found in southern Sussex County and near Wilmington in Delaware.

Common wormsnake

The secretive wormsnake grows to be about 1 foot long. They’re uniformly brown with pinkish bellies. They’re found in a variety of habitats, usually under surface debris, logs or rocks, and eat mainly worms.

Eastern milksnake

Eastern milksnakes have reddish blotches outlined in black, with a cream color in between, and usually grow to be about 3 feet long. They’re another secretive burrower, eating mostly small mammals.

Eastern kingsnake

Eastern kingsnakes are black with thin white crossbars and usually about 4 feet long. They live in a variety of other habitats and are known for eating other snakes, though they also eat a variety of other prey.

Eastern hog-nosed snake

Hog-nosed snakes vary greatly in color, from all black to crossbanded with black, brown, orange, red and gray tones. They are best identified by their turned-up snout. They can grow to between 3 and 4 feet long. Hog-nosed snakes are found in a variety of sandy-soil habitats and eat mostly toads. If approached, they may take a striking position, inflate and hiss, or even feign death.

Ring-necked snake

Ring-necked snakes are usually about 1 foot long. Color ranges from blueish black to gray to brown, with a yellow or cream-colored “ring” around the neck. They inhabit forest surface debris, eating worms, salamanders and skinks.

Smooth earthsnake

Smooth earthsnakes are uniformly reddish-brown to dark gray, often with tiny black flecks. They eat mainly worms and are found in a variety of habitats, mainly underground or under surface debris.

Queensnake

Queensnakes are on the smaller side, reaching a maximum length of 3 feet. Their color ranges from gray to brown to olive green, with two cream-colored or yellowish stripes and sometimes several other dark stripes running their lengths. They’re often confused with garters. Queensnakes are usually found along shallow, rocky streams and eat crayfish almost exclusively.

Rough greensnake

Rough greensnakes grow to be 2-to-3 feet long. They live in trees in a variety of habitats and eat mainly insects.

Common ribbonsnake

Common ribbonsnakes are dark brown or black with three yellow or cream-colored stripes down their length. They can grow to about 2 feet. They are semiaquatic and can be found in many habitats near water, often in trees. They eat mainly frogs, salamanders and small fish.

Red-bellied snake

The red-bellied snake is usually only between eight and 10 inches long. It can be gray, brown or black and has two or four dark stripes. Like Dekay’s brownsnake, the red-bellied snake is nocturnal and can be found in multiple habitats, often under logs, rocks or other debris. They eat slugs almost exclusively.

Red cornsnake

Red cornsnakes can grow to about 4 feet long. They have reddish-brown blotches outlined in black with tan in between. This secretive snake lives in forests and eats mostly rodents.

search_result.title: Whales off the Delaware coast: Your guide to these huge mammals
search_result.text:
Some beachgoers have been delighted to find themselves in the right place at the right time this summer as graceful humpback whales breached the water’s surface along Delaware’s coastline.

These massive marine mammals are not the only whale species known to swim by the First State as they feast on myriad marine life breeding and migrating among the state’s smaller bodies of water this time of year.

Here's a list of the whale species that may be spotted by a lucky few, as well as some do’s and don’ts about interacting with marine life in the area.

Humpback whale

Humpback whales, like those seen by a local volleyball team and paddleboarders this summer, can reach 60 feet in length and weigh up to 80,000 pounds. They enjoy feasting on tiny crustaceans, plankton and small fish, and live at the surface of the ocean and in shallow coastline waters.

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration estimates there are at least 80,000 humpback whales worldwide, about 12,000 of which live in the Atlantic Ocean. The agency declared an unusual mortality event for this whale species in 2016 after an unusual number of whales were found dead or stranded on East Coast beaches. To date, 79 humpback whales have washed ashore from Florida to Maine as part of that mortality event.

Fun fact: Humpback whales can live about 80 to 90 years in the wild, and are known to migrate 5,000 miles per year.

North Atlantic right whale

Known as one of the rarest whale species in the world, the North Atlantic right whale can reach about 50 feet in length and weigh up to 140,000 pounds. They also feast on tiny marine life, largely zooplankton. While they were once found in all of the world’s oceans, they now mainly live in the North Atlantic.

NOAA estimates there are fewer than 500 right whales left, making the species critically endangered. The agency declared an unusual mortality event for this whale species in 2017 when 17 whales were found dead in Canada and the United States.

North Atlantic right whales threatened by climate change and human encounters

Fun fact: A characteristic feature of this species is the raised patches of rough skin on their heads, called callosities, which appear white because of whale lice.

Minke whale

This uniquely shaped whale can reach about 35 feet in length and weigh up to 20,000 pounds. It is another species known to breach the ocean’s surface and delight those lucky enough to be nearby. They feed on small marine animals, such as crustaceans, plankton and small fish and are largely found in temperate or cool waters.

NOAA estimates there is a robust population of minke whales in the world, with about 2,500 living in the Atlantic. The agency also declared an unusual mortality event for this whale species in 2017, and since then, 37 whales have been found dead or stranded on beaches from South Carolina to Maine.

Fun fact: Minke whales are the smallest of baleen whales, which are whales that have plates of whalebone in their mouths to strain plankton from the water.

Pilot whales

Both short-finned and long-finned pilot whales are known to frequent Delaware’s coast, following and feasting on squid. Short-finned pilot whales can reach up to 24 feet and weigh up to 6,600 pounds, while long-finned whales can reach 25 feet and about 5,000 pounds.

NOAA estimates there are about 1,100 short-finned whales in the Gulf of Mexico and eastern Atlantic Ocean, while more than 8,000 long-finned whales are estimated to live in the Atlantic and 200,000 in the Antarctic.

Fun fact: Long-finned pilot whales can dive 2,000 feet deep for about 15 minutes to feed.

Sperm whale

The sperm whale and its smaller relative, the pygmy sperm whale, can be found worldwide, and live year-round in the Gulf of Mexico and along the Atlantic Coast from North Carolina to Georges Bank.

Sperm whales can reach up to 52 feet in length and weigh up to 90,000 pounds. The smaller pygmy version reaches a maximum of about 12 feet and up to 1,000 pounds. Both enjoy feasting on squid, but are also known to hunt other fish. Pygmy sperm whales also enjoy the occasional crustacean.

Sperm whales enjoy deeper waters and are considered endangered, with an estimate of 450,000 left in worldwide waters. It is unclear how many pygmy sperm whales are left, but NOAA estimates there are about 1,000 in the Atlantic and in the Gulf of Mexico.

Fun fact: Sperm whales are named after a waxy substance found on their heads, which is called spermaceti. That substance was historically used for oil lamps, lubricants and candles.

Sei whale

This sleek swimmer can reach up to 60 feet in length and weigh up to 100,000 pounds. They usually live in deeper waters, but will follow their prey — which includes plankton and small crustaceans — into inshore waters.

They are considered endangered, and NOAA estimates there are about 8,600 sei whales in the northern Pacific Ocean, but it is unclear how many remain in other waters.

Fun fact: Sei whales can swim at speeds of 34 miles per hour or faster, and eat about 2,000 pounds of food per day.

Fin whale

As the largest whale species known to frequent Delaware’s coast, fin whales can reach up to 85 feet in length and weigh up to 160,000 pounds. They are known to be fast swimmers, and are usually found in deep, offshore waters around the world.

Fin whales are considered endangered, and NOAA estimates there are about 2,700 left in the North Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico, about 3,200 in the eastern Pacific Ocean and a total of about 82,000 worldwide.

Fun fact: Fin whales sometimes mate with blue whales, and hybrids have been documented.

Orca

Commonly known as killer whales, orcas can reach up to 32 feet in length and weigh up to 22,000 pounds. They eat everything from fish and squid to birds, turtles and other marine mammals.

This species is considered uncommon and found worldwide. NOAA estimates there are fewer than 300 orcas in the Gulf of Mexico, but their population off the East Coast is largely unknown. It is estimated there are about 50,000 worldwide.

Fun fact: The killer whale, or orca, is the largest member of the Delphinidae family, which are oceanic dolphins. Long-finned and short-finned pilot whales also belong to this family.

If you see a whale

Occasionally, large whales wash ashore on Delaware’s beaches, where they can create quite a stir. Marine stranding experts advise people and pets to keep their distance, because the stranded whale — dead or alive — could carry diseases.

Anyone who sees a whale in distress in the water or on the shore should immediately call the Marine Education, Research & Rehabilitation Institute’s 24-hour hotline at (302) 228-5029.

Contact reporter Maddy Lauria at (302) 345-0608, mlauria@delawareonline.com or on Twitter @MaddyinMilford.

search_result.title: Poison hemlock species found recently in Sussex County can be ...
search_result.text:
A hemlock that may be mistaken for a wild carrot, parsnip or celery could cause nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and, in extreme cases, even death.

The Delaware Department of Agriculture is warning Delawareans about two species of hemlock recently found in Sussex County. Scientists confirmed the presence of poison hemlock and spotted water hemlock. All parts of the plants – leaves, stems, flowers and roots – are poisonous to humans and animals.

Both were found in wetland areas in Sussex County.

People who like to forage for food or cut wildflowers are advised to avoid wild carrot-looking plants to prevent the possibility of being poisoned.

TORNADOES: Weather service, after surveying damage, says two tornadoes hit Delaware Thursday

Poison hemlock, an invasive biennial native to Europe, northern Africa and western Asia, grows from 6 to 8 feet tall. It is also known to grow in ditches, meadows, pastures and the edges of cultivated fields. The plant emits an odor, but people should not crush any part of the plant to smell it because toxic alkaline oils can be released, poisoning the person, the Department of Agriculture said.

Spotted water hemlock is a native plant that grows up to 6 feet tall. The stems can vary in color from solid green or purple to green with purple spots or stripes, the Department of Agriculture said. The leaves are lacy and fernlike, with veins ending at the base of the notch of the leaf edge.

If residents suspect they have found either of these plants, take a picture and email it to DDA.Marketing@delaware.gov for identification.

Depending on the exposure – direct contact, ingestion and inhalation – signs and symptoms of poisoning by spotted water hemlock and poison hemlock in humans can appear as soon as 15 minutes to hours and can include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach pain, irregular heartbeat, dilation of the pupils, respiratory distress, muscle damage, renal failure and central nervous system involvement causing seizures, with potential for death, the Department of Agriculture said.

HOLIDAY WEEKEND: How to get around the Delaware beaches during Fourth of July road closures, delays

If you think you've been exposed, call the Poison Control Center at 800-222-1222 or 911.

Toxicity can occur in animals if any part of the plant is ingested. Ingestion of the plant may lead to death within just two to three hours, depending on the amount consumed. Fresh leaves of poison hemlock are not pleasant to animals, so livestock and horses rarely eat hemlock if other feed is available, the Department of Agriculture said.

Clinical signs in livestock usually begin within 30 to 60 minutes after ingestion. There is no treatment or cure. When ingested, the toxin affects nerve impulse transmission to the muscles, and animals die due to respiratory failure. Animals often will be found dead before the illness is determined.

Contact reporter Jeff Neiburg at jneiburg@delawareonline.com. Follow him on Twitter @Jeff_Neiburg.

search_result.title: What to do if you find abandoned or injured young wildlife
search_result.text:
The best thing you can do when you come across young wildlife is to leave it alone.

The Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control has a saying: "If you care, leave them there."

Taking a wild animal from the wild not only decreases its chances of survival, but can be dangerous.

"While some young animals appear to be abandoned, they usually are not, with their mothers nearby watching over them and waiting for you to move on," DNREC said in a statement. "Many wildlife species, including white-tailed deer, leave their young while they forage for food, visiting only a few times a day, with the young animal’s natural instinct to lie quietly to protect them from predators."

LOCAL WILDLIFE:'No other option': How Millsboro bypass will affect rare, threatened, endangered species

Regardless of the situation, if you come across a wild animal, keep your distance.

They can be unpredictable and dangerous, especially if they are in pain, according to DNREC. They can also carry parasites, such as fleas and ticks, and diseases such as rabies. Don't allow children or household pets near wild animals.

If you find young wildlife that appears unharmed, watch from a distance for the mother to return before calling from help. It may be several hours before she returns.

POLLUTION:Maryland appeals court order to regulate chickenhouse ammonia

According to the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, signs a wild animal needs help include:

Evidence of blood.

An obvious broken limb.

A featherless or nearly featherless bird on the ground.

A dead parent nearby.

Audible distress over a prolonged period of time.

BIRDS:Salisbury Zoo's pelicans (literally) flying the coop, now headed for Chicago zoo

The Delaware Council of Wildlife Rehabilitators and Educators offers the following tips for those who find a wild animal that may be in need of assistance:

If it's a young bird, try to locate its nest and place it back inside. If the bird is able to escape from you, leave it alone. It is a fledgling and a parent is nearby.

If it's a nest of rabbits, a parent is likely nearby and they should be left alone. If you've injured one, remove it from the nest and contact rehabilitators.

If you must intervene, use gloves. Place the animal in a cage or a box with a blanket. Offer warmth through a bottle filled with warm water. Do not use an electric heating pad or give the animal medication.

In Delaware, contact DNREC Division of Fish and Wildlife’s Wildlife Section for help related to wild animals in need of assistance. They can be reached during business hours Monday through Friday at 302-739-9912 and at 800-523-3336 after hours and on weekends.

For cases involving birds in Delaware, contact Tri-State Bird Rescue.

In Maryland, call 877-463-6497 for all wildlife assistance cases.

search_result.title: Remember the 'kissing bug?' CDC confirms one was found in ...
search_result.text:
WILMINGTON, Del. – The "kissing bug" – which bites people around their mouth and can pass along the fatal disease Chagas – is making its way north.

In September, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention warned that the deadly bloodsuckers were on the move up from Central and South America and had been reported in Maryland, Pennsylvania and Virginia.

Last week the CDC confirmed an actual sighting in Delaware.

In July, a family from Kent County called the Delaware Division of Public Health and Delaware Department of Agriculture because an insect had bitten their child's face while she was watching TV in her bedroom.

The family lived in an older single-family home near a heavily wooded area, according to a CDC report. There was an air conditioner in the window of the girl's bedroom and the family hadn't traveled anywhere outside the local area.

Staff from the agriculture department preliminarily identified the insect as Triatoma sanguisuga, or the kissing bug.

Want news from USA TODAY on WhatsApp? Click this link on your mobile device to get started

They sent pictures of the insect to Texas A&M University’s Kissing Bug Citizen Science Program, a multidisciplinary research program aimed at documenting and collecting kissing bugs from across the United States.

More:Insidious 'kissing bugs' bite Texas woman

The insect also was sent to the CDC, which did tests and confirmed their findings.

The girl who was bitten did not get sick, though the bugs can carry a deadly disease known as Chagas.

The silent danger

Doctors say the kissing bug is a silent killer.

While it sucks your blood, it defecates. In its feces is a parasite, which finds a home in your tissue, muscles and heart and leads to Chagas disease.

The disease can be fatal, though the chances of contracting it are low.

If a person contracts the disease, symptoms typically include severe redness, itching, swelling, welts and hives, CDC officials say. It can be spread from mother to baby, by blood transfusion and during organ transplants.

Most people only experience minor symptoms. But some, less than half, may develop the following:

Irregular heartbeats that can cause sudden death.

An enlarged heart that doesn't pump blood well.

Problems with digestion and bowel movement.

An increased chance of having a stroke.

The CDC estimates that approximately 300,000 persons with Chagas disease live in the United States, and most were infected with the parasite T. cruzi in parts of Latin America where Chagas disease is found.

Only a few cases of Chagas disease caused by contact with the bugs have been documented in the United States.

For more information, go to www.cdc.gov/parasites/chagas or call 404-718-4745.

How to protect yourself

You can take precautions against the kissing bug. The CDC recommends locating outdoor lights away from dwellings such as homes, dog kennels and chicken coops and turning off lights that are not in use.

Homeowners also should remove trash, wood, and rock piles from around the home and clear out any bird and animal nests.

Cracks and gaps around windows, air conditioners, walls, roofs, doors and crawl spaces into the house should be inspected and sealed.

Chimney flues should be tightly closed when not in use and screens should be used on all doors and windows. Ideally, pets should sleep indoors, especially at night, and outdoor pet resting areas kept clean.

If you suspect you have Chagas disease, consult your health care provider.

How to tell if it's a kissing bug

Adult kissing bugs range from about 0.75 to 1.25 inches in length. Most species have a very characteristic band around the edge of the body that is striped with orange or red markings.

One species (Triatoma protracta) may or may not have a single colored band around the outer edge of the body.

The legs of kissing bugs are long and thin. Unlike some other species, the legs are uniformly thin along the length of the leg, and there are no "bulging" thicker areas.

Kissing bugs have distinctive mouthparts that appear as a large black extension to the head. These mouthparts give rise to the nickname "cone-nose bug.'

There are 11 different species of kissing bugs in the United States. The most common species in the south-central United States are Triatoma sanguisuga and Triatoma gerstaeckeri, which are each about 1 inch long.

Follow Jessica Bies on Twitter: @jessicajbies.

search_result.title: Delmarva's plentiful insects can be annoying, dangerous
search_result.text:
HARRISON JACKSON

COLUMNIST

Warm weather means shorts, T-shirts, tank tops and flip flops, but it also means ticks, chiggers and mosquitoes here on the Eastern Shore. These annoying, irritating and potentially dangerous biting insects thrive here in Maryland during the summer and can make any day spent outside miserable.

There are several species of tick that live in Maryland — including the American dog tick, the brown dog tick, the deer tick and the lone star tick. Ticks are small and dark, often black or brown colored and only about 1/8 of an inch long before attachment, which is why they are so difficult to find when they are on your body.

These tick species prefer slightly different habitats; however, the brown dog tick tends to survive the best of all these species indoors, but suffers outside in woody areas.

The American dog tick, deer tick and lone star tick are often found in wooded areas or fields with tall grass, anywhere there might be high traffic for larger mammals such as deer, foxes, dogs or people to latch onto.

Ticks will attach themselves to a host and travel around the body in search of a preferable feeding spot, like the back of a knee, the back of the head or around the armpits, where they will insert their mouth parts into the skin and begin sucking out the host's blood. If not found and removed, adult ticks can feed on a host for days, until becoming engorged and several times larger than their original size.

FIND OUT MORE: Ticks on Delmarva

About 59 species of mosquitoes live in Maryland, each uniquely suited for the wide array of habitats they inhabit. Mosquito species are locally abundant, which means they have high populations in small areas or habitats; however, there tends to be little overlap in species habitat.

Mosquitoes belong to the order Diptera, or “true flies.” All species must spend some portion of life in water, mostly for the larval and pupal stages. When adult mosquitoes first emerge from their aquatic stages, they mate. Then the female goes off to find blood to provide protein for her fertilized eggs, which she then lays in a moist area or in water.

While there are both male and female mosquitoes, only the females bite, as only females have the proboscis necessary to suck blood. Male mosquitoes feed on plant nectar and lack the mouth parts necessary to break human skin.

To repel Delmarva pests, try taking an au naturale route

Chiggers are very similar to ticks; however, there are some distinct differences. The chiggers that bite humans and other mammals are the juvenile, or larval, form of a mite of the family Trombiculidae. Chiggers are red mites that are extremely small, less than 1/150 of an inch long, and can really only be seen when they congregate in larger numbers.

Like ticks, chiggers live in vegetated areas, like the woods and open fields, and will attach themselves to large mammals that walk by. These tiny mites will migrate around the skin until they find an optimal feeding area with thinner skin, such as the ankles, behind the knees or armpits.

Contrary to popular belief, chiggers do not bury themselves in your skin to feed. Chiggers insert their feeding structures into the skin and inject certain enzymes that cause destruction of host tissue, whether it be human or some other kind of mammal.

Hardening of the surrounding skin results in the formation of a feeding tube called a stylostome, which is what causes the severe skin irritation. Chigger larvae then feed upon the destroyed tissue of the host until dislodged, killed or engorged.

While all three of these insects feed on larger mammals and humans, only ticks and mosquitoes are true vectors, or carriers, of diseases. Thus far in Maryland, chiggers have yet to be connected with transmittable diseases to humans. However, intense scratching at the infestation site can lead to secondary bacterial infections.

It is important to be wary of ticks in Maryland, since they are potential vectors for tularemia, Lyme disease and Rocky Mountain spotted fever. All three diseases can be found in Maryland; however, Lyme disease is the most prevalent.

Mosquitoes are vectors for several diseases as well including malaria, yellow fever and West Nile virus. Only West Nile virus has been known to occur in Maryland.

There are several ways to help prevent getting bitten by one of these troublesome insects. The best way is to wear long clothing, like pants and long sleeved shirts, when traveling in woody areas or open fields, as this will help to keep ticks and chiggers from attaching themselves to your skin while outside.

Bug and insect repellants are also useful, as these will help to keep mosquitoes away as well as other insects, such as horseflies or gnats.

Preventative measures may not be enough, so after a day outdoors everyone should give themselves a full body tick and chigger check to see if they have any unwanted hitchhikers.

Harrison Jackson is the former education coordinator for Maryland Coastal Bays Program.

UTHSC team receives $2.19 million to study neurotoxicity of commonly-used chemical solvent

Memphis, Tenn. (June 20, 2022) – A team of University of Tennessee Health Science Center researchers has been awarded $2.19 million from the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences for their investigation of the neurotoxic effects of toluene, a common chemical found in many household products.

Alex M. Dopico, MD, Van Vleet Chair of Excellence and professor in the Department of Pharmacology, Addiction Science, and Toxicology (PHAST) in the UTHSC College of Medicine, and Anna N. Bukiya, PhD, professor in the same department, are principal investigators on the award. Jeff Steketee, PhD, also professor in the PHAST Department and chair of the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee, is a co-investigator.

Toluene reaches the brain through inhalation. Intoxication with toluene, whether accidental or following recreational use (e.g., “glue sniffing”), leads to dizziness, blurred vision and even neurological deficits with catastrophic outcomes, including death. A reduction in blood flow to the brain is thought to contribute to these toxic effects, but how and why toluene exposure affects the brain circulation is not known.

The team hypothesizes that toluene reduces the activity of a protein (the BK channel) located in the cerebral artery muscle cells, causing the brain arteries to constrict upon exposure. Performing tests at the molecular level using computational methods, and in vitro and in vivo evaluation of BK channel function in animal models, the team aims to identify the specific mechanism and site of action in BK channels that makes cerebral arteries constrict in the presence of toluene. Their tests will include delivering new selective drug therapies for early intervention in toluene-induced brain ischemia.

The project, titled “Ionic mechanisms of toluene cerebrovascular actions,” is being funded over five years.

The TRAC20 is an advanced, high-performance aircraft that will be used for initial pilot training at the only ab-initio flight academy operated by one of the largest U.S.-based airlines. Currents: Recent Art from East Tennessee and Beyond, pays tribute to contemporary women artists represented in the collection of the KMA

This exhibition, a special edition of the KMA’s permanent installation Currents: Recent Art from East Tennessee and Beyond, pays tribute to contemporary women artists represented in the collection of the Knoxville Museum of Art. This show and Women Artists: Highlights from the Hunter Museum of American Art (one floor up) document what two important Tennessee cultural organizations are doing to support and empower women artists.

Like the Hunter, the KMA has actively sought to acquire outstanding works by women, who have long lagged behind their male counterparts when it comes to museum-level recognition. The selection on view reflects the broad technical and aesthetic range found in contemporary art by women. A mixed media painting on wooden sections by Alison Moritsugu conveys a monumental landscape, expansive yet incomplete. Nancy Rubins elevates graphite drawing into a large sculptural construction apparently shaped by violent forces. British artist Marilène Oliver constructs provocative portraits of her family in the form of acrylic sheets imprinted with digital medical scans. Patty Chang uses water and mirrors to transform her own image taken in a Belgian church into a complex photographic work fragmented by harsh angles and provocative reflections. In her video Joan of Arc, Alex McQuilkin responds to Maria Falconetti’s memorable lead role in the legendary 1928 French silent film by Carl Dreyer, and to the film’s themes of adolescent desire, faith, and suffering. These and other selected works call overdue attention to women’s significant role in reshaping the contemporary art landscape.

The artists featured in this exhibition are Patty Chang, Janet Fish, Marcia Goldenstein, Michelle Grabner, EJ Hauser, Julie Heffernan, Jean Hess, Kate Katomski, Karen LaMonte, Pam Longobardi, Lauren Luloff, Alex McQuilkin, Alison Mortisugu, Althea Murphy-Price, Marilène Oliver, Amy Pleasant, Sumi Putman, Nancy Rubins, Tommie Rush, Denise Stewart-Sanabria, Jemima Stehli, and Toots Zynsky.
