search_result.title: NJ election 2023: Democrats hold state Senate, Assembly
search_result.text:
Democrats are poised to retain control of the New Jersey Legislature, as some districts thought to be vulnerable fell their way — including Bergen County's 38th.

District 38 — a longtime Democratic stronghold represented by incumbent state Sen. Joe Lagana and Assembly members Lisa Swain and Chris Tully — was considered a possible flip for Republicans.

But the race was called in Lagana's favor by the Associated Press very early Wednesday. By midday, with 97% of the vote counted, Lagana held a 27,260 to 20,878 vote lead over challenger Micheline Attieh.

Swain and Tully, with 97% of the vote tallied, held slimmer leads over challengers Gail Horton and Barry Wilkes. Swain and Tully had 26,555 votes and 26,155, respectively, compared to Wilkes and Horton, with 21,013 and 21,022, respectively. The Associated Press called the race in the Democrats' favor late Wednesday morning.

The winning Democrats, led by Bergen County chairman Paul Juliano, entered a ballroom at the Hasbrouck Heights Hilton at 12:38 a.m. — as Bruce Springsteen’s "Born to Run" played in the background — to declare victory.

Prep for the polls: See who is running for president and compare where they stand on key issues in our Voter Guide

“If you look at what happened all over the state, Democrats won,” Lagana said. “Because we ran on good issues and we ran on real issues. Republicans ran on false issues and spread absolute nonsense across the state and the voters saw through it.”

District 38 was redistricted last year, potentially shifting the political balance. The district lost Passaic County's Hawthorne and gained Teterboro, South Hackensack, Little Ferry and Moonachie. The remainder of the district includes Bergenfield, Fair Lawn, Glen Rock, Hasbrouck Heights, Lodi, Maywood, New Milford, Oradell, Paramus, River Edge, Rochelle Park and Saddle Brook.

The election results released throughout the state Tuesday are not official and are not set to be certified until Nov. 22.

NJ election results 2023:Polls have closed, some races called

Gopal wins in battleground Shore district

District 11 in Monmouth County, viewed by many as a battleground and the only one in the state with split representation, appeared to be a win for Democrats as the early, unofficial results rolled in.

Incumbent state Sen. Vin Gopal said that “Monmouth County showed up in numbers we have not seen before in an off-year election” and that he and his running mates are “thrilled that our entire ticket has earned the overwhelming support of voters.”

If the results hold up, his running mates, Margie Donlon and Luanne Peterpaul, would be first-time members of the Assembly.

“To be the first female practicing physician legislator in New Jersey history is an awesome responsibility that I do not take lightly,” Donlon said. “On the campaign trail, I vowed to always follow facts and science when making decisions in the Assembly and I am excited to fulfill that promise.”

Peterpaul said she is “beyond humbled to have earned the support of Monmouth County residents” and that she is “also humbled to be making history as the first openly gay woman elected to the New Jersey Legislature.”

“I stand on the shoulders of countless trailblazers who fought for equality and opened the door for people like me to serve my community in elected office,” she said.

State Senate, Assembly results:Control of the New Jersey Statehouse on the line in 2023

Ed Durr — who unseated Senate President Steve Sweeney — is out

Another race many were monitoring closely, District 3 — made up of parts of Cumberland, Gloucester and Salem counties — seemed set to return to Democratic control.

Incumbent state Sen. Ed Durr trailed former Assemblyman John Burzichelli by nearly 5,000 votes late Tuesday night as results continued to roll in. Durr shocked the state political machine two years ago with a grassroots victory over then-state Senate President Steve Sweeney.

Meanwhile, Democrats may have gained a seat in the Assembly in District 30 with Democrat Alexander Schnall leading incumbent Assemblyman Ed Thomson. Republican Assemblyman Sean Kean was reelected in the district that includes towns in Monmouth and Ocean counties.

In Atlantic County’s District 2 race, the Republican incumbents appeared to fend off a challenge from a reshuffled Democratic slate. In that race, Sen. Vince Polistina and Assembly members Don Guardian and Claire Swift seem likely to retain their seats.

A rematch two years in the making in District 16 saw state Sen. Andrew Zwicker poised to beat Republican Michael Pappas for the second time. The district includes parts of Mercer, Somerset, Hunterdon and Middlesex counties, and was expected to be competitive by many throughout the state.

Zwicker’s running mates, incumbent Assemblyman Roy Freiman and Mitchelle Drulis, who is seeking to replace Assemblywoman Sadaf Jaffer, also held leads late Tuesday night.

Early voting, mail-in ballots — and expected low turnout

Polls were open for 10 days of early in-person voting and for 14 hours on Election Day. Voters who requested ballots to vote by mail, nearly 920,000 in all, had weeks to submit them. Election reforms enacted over the last few years have made it possible for those ballots — if they were postmarked by Tuesday — to be considered valid as long as they are received by Nov 13.

Turnout was expected to be low this year, as it historically has been in years without statewide or federal races atop the ballots.

More than 545,000 votes had been cast before the polls even opened on Tuesday — 124,197 from early in-person voting and 421,573 from vote-by-mail ballots, according to the state’s Division of Elections — equaling about 8% of the 6,494,988 registered voters in New Jersey.

Assembly seats are up for grabs every two years but when it comes to the state Senate, New Jersey subscribes to a "2-4-4" approach to elections, where seats are up for election every four years except for the first term of a new decade. This allows for the latest reapportionment to be used as soon as possible.

Need to know:Our guide to New Jersey's 2023 elections for Legislature, local offices and school boards

Competitive races and the issues

Though all 120 seats in the Legislature were up for grabs on Tuesday, much of the attention in the run-up to Election Day was focused on a handful of races and a few issues.

Democrats, who have controlled both the Assembly and the state Senate for two decades, spent considerable time and money trying to paint their opponents as radical extremists, warning of a rollback of reproductive health care rights.

Meanwhile, New Jersey Republicans have been much more focused on parental rights in schools and tapping into a base that is angry about New Jersey Department of Education policy, which limits the ability of school officials to notify parents when a child is signaling a change in gender.

Another issue that has been at the forefront, especially in the week leading up to Election Day, is wind energy. The decision by Danish company Ørsted to cancel its plans to develop two massive wind farms off the South Jersey coast was a disappointment to clean energy advocates, but the project has drawn reproach from Republicans throughout the campaign season. They alleged that early work on the project was killing whales.

The Democrats were the majority party in both chambers of the Legislature going into Election Day, with a 25 to 15 majority in the Senate and a 46 to 34 majority in the Assembly, but many voters can expect to see some shakeup in their districts merely because so many lawmakers have decided it’s time to move on.

There were nearly two dozen legislators who decided not to run again and one who lost in the primary in June. Assemblyman Joseph Egan announced his retirement in July, and just a few weeks later, state Sen. Dick Codey announced his retirement after spending half a century in the Legislature.

This was also the first legislative election to use the newly drawn maps based on the 2020 census results.

Katie Sobko covers the New Jersey Statehouse. Email: sobko@northjersey.com

search_result.title: NJ election 2023: Biggest changes North Jersey voters made
search_result.text:
Who did North Jersey voters choose to represent them in town councils, the Statehouse, school boards and more in 2023?

On the state legislative level, Democrats declared victory, holding the Senate and gaining five seats in the Assembly, but the local level is messier. Some incumbents from both parties were overthrown, parental rights candidates for various school boards won and lost, and power shifted among seats across Bergen, Passaic, Morris and Sussex counties.

It was a low-turnout election, often the case when there are no presidential, congressional or gubernatorial names on the ticket. Though all 120 seats in Trenton's Legislature were up for grabs, as of Thursday, 29.5% of registered Bergen County voters had cast their ballots, according to data provided by the county clerk's office, compared with 44.3% the year prior and 75.1% in 2020 when Joe Biden and Donald Trump faced off for president.

Of course, mail-in ballots are still being counted. As long as a mail-in ballot was postmarked by Election Day and is received by Nov. 13, election officials will tally those votes. And after all other votes are counted, officials turn to the paper provisional ballots.

But based on unofficial results, here are the notable narratives that reporters for NorthJersey.com and the USA TODAY Network New Jersey found while sifting through election data.

Prep for the polls: See who is running for president and compare where they stand on key issues in our Voter Guide

38th District Democrats keep seats

The Democratic incumbents, Sen. Joe Lagana and Assembly members Lisa Swain and Chris Tully, held on to their seats in a newly drawn district that covers parts of Bergen and Passaic counties after spending millions of dollars to defeat Republican challengers Micheline Attieh, Gail Horton and Barry Wilkes.

Democrats have held full control of the district since 2004, but it was considered a possible flip for Republicans this year.

Super PACs and other independent expenditure groups on both sides spent hundreds of thousands of dollars trying to tip the scales, using funds raised from unions, advocacy groups and philanthropists.

“If you look at what happened all over the state, Democrats won,” Lagana said. “Because we ran on good issues and we ran on real issues. Republicans ran on false issues and spread absolute nonsense across the state, and the voters saw through it.”

Bergen County Dems keep commissioner seats

Democrats running for the Bergen County Board of Commissioners declared victory in the early hours of Wednesday as results rolled in around 1 a.m.

Incumbent Democrats Joan Voss and Rafael Marte will keep their seats as commissioners after defeating Republican challengers Agninshalah Collins and Mary Jo-Ann Guinchard. Marte, a former councilman in Bergenfield, was chosen to fill the seat of former Commissioner Ramon Hache, who stepped down in March. Voss said this was her 14th election.

Republicans have not held a seat on the commissioners' board since 2013.

Parental rights candidates lose in Westwood, Sparta

Voters rejected a parental rights slate of school board candidates for the Westwood Regional School District, unseating two incumbents, Irene Fenarjian and James Parrino.

Four political newcomers are poised to take seats on the nine-member board: Washington Township residents Heather Perin, Loni Azzolina and Jorge Pertuz, and Westwood resident Nicole Martin, who ran together focusing on “equitable public education for all students.”

The election followed months of tense debate in the district, which serves about 2,800 students from Washington Township and Westwood, with hundreds packing school meetings since April to discuss the board majority's decisions to push back on sex education standards, comments that seemed to denigrate same-sex parents, and a policy that led to the removal of LGBTQ+ pride signs outside school properties.

The Sparta Board of Education lost two incumbents as voters chose three members of a “Stop Raising Taxes” team over the “Voices of Reason” candidates. The slate of Kaitlin Gagnon, Jennifer Grana and Chad Wood defeated the team of Dana Dumpert, Robert Meara and incumbent Christina Longo-Keiling, as well as incumbent LeeAnne Pitzer, who ran independently under the "Students First” banner.

In October, the township’s Board of Education rescinded its policy regarding transgender students, meaning it will consider on a case-by-case basis whether to notify parents if a student requests an accommodation regarding their gender identity or change of pronouns.

Decisions including policy changes about mature reading material led to a no-confidence vote by the teachers' union against five board members, including Pitzer and Longo-Keiling.

"By focusing on the actual issues facing our Sparta district over dog-whistle political movements, we strive to redirect the board’s focus to fund allocation, facilities, staff retention, and our declining district rankings," the “Stop Raising Taxes” team said, pointing to a 5.8% tax increase in the budget approved earlier in the year, which they called “reckless fiscal management.”

Parental rights slates win in Morris districts

In Morris County, however, parental rights candidates were leading heated school board races in Hanover and Roxbury.

In Hanover, “Students Matters Most” candidates Michelle Stricchiola, William McCabe and Christopher Mattessich — who didn’t participate in an October candidates forum — led over the “Focus on Education” ticket, Christina Dunne, Karen Mascolo and Brian Gibbons.

In May, New Jersey Attorney General Matt Platkin sued the Hanover Township school district, requesting an emergency court order to stop it from implementing a policy requiring teachers to tell parents the gender identity and sexual orientation of LGBTQ+ students. In October, a Morris County judge temporarily blocked the policy from taking effect.

In Roxbury, the parental rights “Back to Basics” slate of incumbent Anne Colucci, Valerie Galdieri and Camilo Bonilla held a lead over the “Kids First” candidates, Dan Masi, Kimberly Schwartz and incumbent Heather Champagne.

Hundreds packed Roxbury school board meetings in the spring to discuss LGBTQ-related library books. Roxbury High librarian Roxanna Caivano sued four residents alleging defamation after they accused her of aiding pedophiles by allowing some state-approved books in the library. The case is pending.

Longest-serving Paterson school board member headed for defeat

In a race with nine contenders fighting for three school board seats, the longest-serving Paterson Board of Education member, Jonathan Hodges — an incumbent of 20 years — appeared to have lost his post.

The highest vote-getter, Mohammad Rashid, has avoided local candidate forums, and education activists say they have not seen Rashid at a Paterson school board meeting. He was backed by a coalition of City Council members allied with Mayor Andre Sayegh and key figures in the Passaic County Democratic Party, and was boosted by a Washington-based super PAC attacking Paterson school tax increases.

Kenneth Simmons, a 12-year school board veteran, was in second place, while the third seat was a nail-biter. Former school board member Corey Teague led by 14 votes over another former member, Vincent Arrington, as of Thursday morning. Former board member Joel Ramirez was within fighting distance in fifth place.

Morristown approves leaf blower ban

Gas-powered leaf blowers won’t be allowed to be used in Morristown from January through September, as voters approved the ban 1,345 to 1,120 as of Thursday. The Morristown council agreed to put the matter to the voters after failing to approve the ban earlier in the year. In Essex County, Montclair is battling multiple lawsuits after passing a similar ban.

Clifton school board incumbents ousted

In Clifton’s Board of Education election for three seats, incumbents Jim Smith and Fahim Abedrabbo lost reelection, with newcomers Joseph Siano, Tanya Suarez and returning former trustee Joseph Canova garnering the most votes.

In Passaic County, Dems win county races, GOP dominates municipal level

Democrats swept Passaic County races, with Danielle Ireland-Imhof besting Rosemary Pino in the race for county clerk, and incumbents Bruce James and Orlando Cruz beating out Republicans Kelley Amico and Adrena Pegel for the Board of County Commissioners.

In municipal races, however, Republicans won a majority of seats, including in Ringwood, Pompton Lakes, Wanaque and West Milford, and unopposed races in Totowa and North Haledon.

Democrats won races in Bloomingdale and had unopposed races in Woodland Park and Haledon.

Voters also approved three public questions: In Clifton, they sanctioned an open space tax of 1 cent per $100 of assessed property value. In Woodland Park, they consented to a non-binding measure increasing the open space tax to 3 cents per $100 of assessed value. In Little Falls, the Board of Education will cut two of its nine members by 2026.

Oakland mayor post back to Republican

Republican Eric Kulmala appeared to have beaten incumbent Democrat Linda Schwager for the Oakland mayoral seat by a tight margin, a reverse of the 2019 race, in which Schwager beat Kulmala by 63 votes.

The vote returns the borough to an all-male and Republican mayor and council. Republican councilmen Russell Talamini and Pasquale “Pat” Pignatelli were re-elected, beating Democratic challengers Andrea Levy and former councilman John Biale.

Wayne 'Children First' candidates win

Incumbent President Donald Pavlak Jr. and newcomers Mark Faber and Wendy Limandri, running under a “Children First” slogan, won three seats on the Wayne Board of Education, beating out Ehab Husein and former board member Suzanne Pudup, who lost her seat last year.

Former Mahwah board member topped field

Brett Coplin, who lost a reelection bid last fall, won the most votes for one of three open seats on the Mahwah Board of Education. Incumbent first Vice President Richard DeSilva Jr. and newcomer Janine Ting Jansen won the other two spots, defeating Danielle Ryan, Michelle Salzman and Geoffrey Lichtenheim.

Closter council Democrats ousted

The Democratic incumbents on the Closter Borough Council, Dolores Witko and Scott Devlin, appeared to have been ousted by Republican challengers Christopher Cho and Anna Maroules. Cho and Maroules won 1,000 and 959 votes, respectively, compared with Witko's 862 and Devin's 852, as of Thursday morning.

Dem edges out GOP incumbent for Cresskill council

A Democratic challenger overthrew one of the two Republican incumbents running for reelection to the Cresskill Borough Council. Arthur McLaughlin received 796 votes, compared with incumbent Republican James Cleary’s 789, as of Thursday morning. Republican incumbent Hector Olmo received the most votes, with 808.

Elmwood Park council president unseated

In the race in Elmwood Park, a Republican challenger unseated Democratic Borough Council President Sandra Balistrieri. Republican Pamela Troisi, who lost her race for a seat last year, had received 1,716 votes to Balistrieri’s 1,392 as of Thursday morning. Incumbent Lorraine Pellegrine — a longtime Democrat who switched to Republican earlier this year — held on to her seat with the most votes, 1,801.

Englewood Cliffs school board incumbent ousted

Jennifer Drimones earned the most votes, 680, for one of three Englewood Cliffs Board of Education seats, edging out incumbent Aman Nahar, who had gotten 473 votes as of Thursday morning. Two other incumbents held on: Philip Choi and Kimara Patton, with 612 and 549 votes, respectively.

Hackensack board incumbent gained fewest votes in field of nine

Andrew Jude Meehan, a retired military officer appointed to the Hackensack school board in June, received the fewest votes — 431 — among nine candidates jockeying for three seats. Candidates Mark Stein, Kenneth Martin and Shivonnie Pringle had the most votes as of Thursday morning, with 1,960, 1,913 and 1,755.

Harrington Park school incumbent out

Jennifer Helfman edged out one of two incumbents fighting for two seats on the Harrington Park school board, getting 655 votes. Incumbent Stephen Hahm had the second-most votes, 631, as of Thursday morning, and incumbent Peter Toomin trailed with 503.

Northvale council Democrat edged out

Democrat John Hogan appeared to have lost his seat on the Northvale Borough Council. Republicans Laura Fernandez and Hovannes Bakalian got 646 and 621 votes, respectively compared with Hogan's 542 votes as of Thursday morning.

Palisades Park school board incumbent out

The only incumbent running for the school board in Palisades Park, Hea Young “Helen” Jeon, received the fewest votes among the field of six competing for three seats. As of Thursday morning, Sookyung Park had the most votes, with 732, with Boyoung Yu in second at 677. Yongman Kim and Aaron Pak were tied for third, with 644 votes each.

Paramus council Democrat out

Democratic incumbent Mariaelena Bellinger lost her seat on the Paramus Borough Council, bested by Republicans Mary Ellen Rizzo and Alfredo Nadera, who had received 3,966 and 3,921 votes to her 2,764 as of Thursday morning.

Ridgefield school incumbent or two unseated

It appears an incumbent or two may lose their seats on the Ridgefield Board of Education, as challengers Lori Hoffman and Theodore Christolias led the pack with 810 and 560 votes. Incumbent Andrew Louis Grippa was holding third, at 531 votes, with his colleagues Melissa Vudragovic and Rafael Morilla-Fraga trailing with 512 and 328 votes as of Thursday morning for three open seats.

Ridgewood school board incumbent out

Michael Lembo lost his seat on Ridgewood’s school board, with newcomer Mary Micale and incumbent Saurabh Dani holding the most votes as of Thursday morning for two open seats.

River Edge district incumbent gets fewest votes

Incumbent Bobby Abraham Kuriakose received the fewest votes in a five-way race for two seats on the River Edge Board of Education. Incumbent Elizabeth Brown and Joshua Koen led the pack.

One Rochelle Park school board incumbent out

At least one incumbent appeared to have been edged out in the race for three seats on the Rochelle Park school board, as Christina Holz had the second-highest vote count, 544, competing against three incumbents. Scott Kral and Joseph Marolda seem to be holding their spots, with 546 and 536 votes, and incumbent Charles Schaadt was in last place with 395 votes as of Thursday morning.

Teaneck Board of Education incumbent out

Incumbent Nadia Hosein appeared to have lost a seat on the Teaneck school board, in fifth place as of Thursday in a race for three seats. Gerald Kirshenbaum, David Gruber and James Wolff were in the top three spots.

Woodcliff Lake council incumbent out

Republicans Julie Brodsky and Joshua Stern were in the lead for two spots on the Woodcliff Lake Borough Council, pushing out Democratic incumbent Richard Schnoll.

There were several other races with incumbents behind but by such small margins that they were too close to call, given that mail-in and provisional ballots had yet to be included in the tally.

While often sparsely attended in past years, school board meetings in some communities are becoming more crowded and controversial with topics like in-person vs. virtual instruction, mask mandates, safety concerns, bullying, transgender policies and parents' involvement in curriculum choices.

In Kent County, residents will have the chance to choose representatives on boards during elections Tuesday, May 9, in Smyrna, Caesar Rodney and Milford school districts, while three districts don't have elections – Capital, Lake Forest and Woodbridge – because candidates were unopposed.

How do I vote in Delaware school board elections? The basics

Voters must be at least 18 years old and live in the district where they are casting a ballot. Proof of ID and address will be requested, such as a driver's license, ID card or U.S. mail with street address. Being registered to vote in state and federal elections is not required, nor is having children in schools.

Polls will open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m., May 9, with various locations across each district. Voters can also request an absentee ballot.

Delaware's school board election guide:Who's running in New Castle County?

Polling places

Allen Frear Elementary, 238 Sorghum Mill Road, Camden-Wyoming

W.B. Simpson Elementary, 5 Old North Road, Wyoming

She has two children who have graduated from the CR District and one attending now. She’s served as a board member at Early College High School and for four years as first vice president for the national sorority Phi Delta Kappa-Alpha Pi Chapter. She declined to give her age or political party, saying, “I am not influenced by a political party and instead am running with the focus of what is in the best interest of our students. The group that will be influencing the decisions I make are the citizens of the Caesar Rodney School District, the families and the students.”

Issues: The top three factors that motivated her to run for the board are the need for equity, transparency and more parent engagement. She said the most important issues in districts across the country, not just in CR, are staff retention and safety.

While the district referendum April 22 didn’t pass, Prophet Brinkley said she was in favor of the plan: “The referendum would have allowed the district to increase educators' salaries and make needed repairs for our schools.”

As for controversial issues such as critical race theory, parental involvement in a district’s curriculum choices and transgender policies, she said she wouldn’t comment on critical race theory specifically but, “Culturally relative/culturally responsive teaching is a priority. I believe parental involvement in the district's curriculum choices should be taken into consideration. Regarding transgender policies, I believe we should treat all individuals like we would want to be treated and that is with love, respect and support.”

Nicole Hill, 44, Dover

Background: Hill is the Kent County coordinator for Read Aloud Delaware since March 2021, recruiting, training and coordinating volunteers to read in childcare centers and writing grant proposals to help fund the program. She worked for the Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control as an environmental scientist and program manager. She has three children who attend district schools and listed her political affiliation as independent.

Issues: Hill decided to run for the board because, “I am a proud CR graduate and I received an excellent education that helped to prepare me for college and the workforce. I want the same, or better, for all of the students attending CR schools.” She is concerned about the safety of students and staff and heard other parents express concerns. “As a mom of three kids that attend schools in the district and a wife of a CR teacher, I felt that I could offer a unique perspective in these areas as well as many others.”

She said the top issue is the recruitment and retention of quality educators. She favors competitive pay, expanding the search for candidates by also recruiting outside Delaware and using alternative certification programs for those with degrees other than in education. She wants to encourage students interested in becoming teachers by promoting the high school’s education pathway.

As for the district referendum that failed April 22, Hill was initially against the plan, "but after attending one of the district meetings explaining the need for the referendum, I felt that I had a much better understanding of why it was necessary.” She said the district should improve communication with the community and explain what’s been done to cut expenses before asking for another referendum because an increase in taxes is difficult for most families, including hers. "However, it is challenging for the district to continue to provide high-quality programs as well as recruit and maintain quality educators without adequate operating funds,” she said.

On controversial issues like critical race theory, parental involvement in a district’s curriculum choices and transgender policies, Hill said, “Students should have access to a wide variety of educational resources. Schools should foster an environment that encourages the exploration of different perspectives and ideas while ensuring that materials are developmentally appropriate. I am in favor of parental involvement in the district’s curriculum choices.”

School boards should listen to families, review the curriculum, seek expert advice, consider alternatives and communicate the decisions transparently.

“All students have the right to access quality education without discrimination,” she said.

Emily Phelan, 40, Magnolia

Background: An Air Force veteran, Phelan also worked as a medical receptionist and is now a Realtor. She is the Allen Frear Elementary PTA vice president with a daughter who attends the school and a stepson who graduated from the district. As for political affiliation, she said she's fiscally conservative but more libertarian in her views that political/social agendas shouldn’t be part of public school education.

Issues: She was motivated to run for the board because teachers need help, students are falling behind particularly with low reading and math scores, and change is needed. She said the top issue in the district is disciplinary discrepancy. She favors examining discipline policies to make them more consistent, with more accountability and transparency. “We need to have ground rules. They need to be clear cut," Phelan said. "While younger children need more guidance in what is right and wrong, by the time the older students are getting ready to go out into the world, they need to be better prepared for the consequences of their actions.”

As for the district referendum that failed April 22, Phelan said she realizes the district needs help, but she was against this referendum because she wants more transparency about how the district is spending money. She believes schools need financial help, “but this was asking too much, too fast with too little information.”

On controversial issues like critical race theory, transgender policies and parental involvement in a district’s curriculum choices, Phelan said, “I’m all for parental rights in schools. Issues: Fontaine St. Pierre decided to run for the board because she wants to serve as “a liaison between parents, teachers and the community, providing the best resources for our children's education, and allowing parents to have the most influence in their children's life.” She wants to recognize and prioritize instructors' interests and concerns.

She said the most important issues in the district are continuing to push for high-quality, intellectually-rigorous education to prepare students for the competitive labor market, providing safe schools, confronting bullying and cyberbullying, and expanding self-esteem initiatives for students.

search_result.title: NJ primary: Should schools in session be used as voting sites?
search_result.text:
The most recent school shooting has re-ignited the debate on whether or not schools should be used as voting sites, especially when students are present.

At least twice each year, hundreds of New Jersey schools are open to staff, students, teachers and any local adult with a voter ID.

This will once again be the case on June 5 — the state's primary election.

Voters are generally confined to libraries, gyms and the halls and walkways leading to and from the parking lot on election days. However, a lack of scrutiny, deterrents, or escort can lead voters to roam halls shared by students in search of a bathroom, water fountain or curiosity fix.

So why are schools still used as voting sites? Accessibility. The schools are accessible to voters because of their central locations and they are accessible to voters with disabilities.

Closter takes a stand

The associated fears of a more sinister motive to roam led by Parkland and other school shootings recently culminated in the elimination of the Hillside Elementary and Tenakill Middle schools as polling locations in Closter, said Joanne Newberry, district superintendent.

After a seven-year push from district officials and residents, the schools are due to be replaced this June by the borough’s senior center and library.

“In this world, like it or not, things have changed and we have to be more careful,” Newberry said. “It took a lot of time, but it was well worth the fight."

On Election Day 2016, more than 3,600 voters passed through Closter’s two schools, records show. There were no negative interactions, though one student had a bit of a scare when a senior citizen ended up in a bathroom reserved for second-graders, Newberry said.

“You really have no idea who’s walking in,” Newberry said. “Sometimes people would end up near the classrooms, and that’s very problematic.”

Of the 147 municipalities in Bergen, Essex, Passaic and Morris counties, 92 have voting in schools – ranging from pre-K to post-graduate – per unofficial election records obtained by The Record and NorthJersey.com in late March.

Which schools are used as polling sites?

In Bergen and Passaic counties, schools account for roughly half of all polling places. That ratio falls to about 1 in 3 in Essex County and 1 in 4 in Morris County.

State statute calls for county boards to contact owners of private buildings suitable for polling. However, preference for polling locations is statutorily given to schools and public buildings without “detrimental interruption of school or the usual public services," state law states.

As recently as 2016, Haledon school board officials cited the potential for disruptions and security threats when unsuccessfully petitioning the Passaic County Board of Elections to eliminate polling from schools.

Despite concern and inconveniences for students and staff, the reasons for polling in nearly 390 schools across Bergen, Essex, Morris, and Passaic counties are convincing. Schools are often well dispersed in a community’s voting districts, near ample parking, and accessible to those with disabilities.

Domenick Stampone, Haledon's mayor, said the convenience and the free lesson in civics far outweigh any speculative security concerns.

“It must be stressed that we have offered to assist (the school district) with security, traffic details, et cetera,” Stampone said. “Voting is an American tradition like no other. Schools should welcome the event.”

Obstacles to relocation

In New Jersey, county boards of elections are charged with determining polling locations with the assistance of municipal clerks.

The most common factors preventing relocation are wheelchair and public accessibility, said John Currie of the Passaic County Board of Elections. The locations must be near or within district boundaries and able to accommodate the maximum turnout, he added.

“Accessibility is the key,” Currie said. “This is our democracy and we want to give every voter every opportunity to vote and make it convenient as for the voters as we possibly can.”

Accessibility has kept voting at the Paradise Knoll Elementary School in West Milford for more than 15 years. Formerly located at a nearby church, the polling location moved to the school following a property maintenance disagreement, according to local officials.

Beyond being “dangerous to give people essentially unrestricted access to schools,” the persistence of voting at the school is unfair to staff attempting to educate, said Kate Romeo, a school parent.

“They have to worry about the social, emotional well-being of students in addition to instruction and security already – without having to deal with thousands of people walking in to the school,” she said.

Rocco DiAntonio, another school parent, said enough public pressure should force a move. However, Lou Signorino, a West Milford councilman, said attempts to find an alternate venue have been genuine, yet unsuccessful.

A town-owned firehouse and ambulance building are in the district but have deficient accessibility and parking, he said. Two churches in the district have also recently rejected requests to take on voting, Cytowicz said. The church representatives expressed their own concerns about safety and the cost of hiring additional security during elections, he said.

“I completely understand,” Cytowicz said. “There are church shootings too.”

Schools said no to voters

Jefferson County, Colorado, banned voting in schools following the 1999 school shooting at Columbine High School that killed 13 people and injured 20 others. West Virginia and Rhode Island close all public schools during primary and general elections.

Currie has suggested legislation that would give New Jersey students the day off, as has Joan Voss, a Bergen County freeholder who served as a state assemblywoman from 2004 to 2012.

A 2013 study by the Presidential Commission on Election Administration also suggested making Election Day an in-service day for schools. Per the report, about a quarter of the nation’s votes were cast in schools in 2008 and 2012.

“In the end, there is no better alternative than schools,” the report stated. “There are few locations more familiar and convenient to voters.”

The suggestions to allow voters access to student-free schools have gained little traction in New Jersey, however, despite the inconvenience and confusion that can come with relocation spurred by school security concerns, said Voss, a former educator.

West Milford officials closed all eight district schools in 2016 to cope with an expected record turnout for the presidential election. On that day, 1,678 of 2,457 eligible registered voters cast ballots at the school, county records show. Turnout dropped to 1,011 voters in 2017, when schools were open.

The district's schools are set to remain open on election days through the 2019 primary, records show. However, district calendar changes as urged by Romeo and other parents are still possible, Cytowicz said.

“We may lose this type of day in the middle of the week during a snow storm,” he said. “To me, it’s no big difference."

Miguel Hernandez, the Haledon superintendent, said closing schools remains a tough sell. Further disrupting what is already a three-day Election Day week due to the state teacher convention is not necessarily ideal, he said. Non-holiday closures or half-day schedules also often create a need for many parents to arrange child care, he added.

Elisabeth Ginsburg, the president of the Glen Ridge Board of Education, said an aversion to closing schools led the district to solicit Glen Ridge Women's Club officials to open their venue to voting in the wake of the 2012 Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting in Newtown, Connecticut.

“Our only other alternative would have been to close schools on polling days, which would have meant a loss of instructional time that we would have had to make up by either shortening breaks or keeping school open longer in June,” Ginsburg said.

Security strategies

In New Milford, district officials responded to recent school shootings by adding two full-time school resource officers. The district now has one specially trained officer in each of its four schools, three of which are used for polling.

Michael Polizzi, the district superintendent, said the measure eliminates the need to contract the local police on election days. However, he said the added security personnel does not excuse “inviting total strangers into a school building during a school day.”

“You wouldn’t do it in your home,” Polizzi said. “You have no idea who’s coming into that school building.”

Wayne DeAngelo, the state Assembly’s deputy speaker (D – Mercer, Middlesex), sponsors a bill that would require schools to have state-approved security plans and state-funded uniformed officers or other protections in place to maintain school operations during elections.

"If the kids are going to be there, and the district doesn't want to shut down, then we should be working to ensure the protection of the kids," he said. "The simplest way to do that is through the presence of law enforcement."

DeAngelo's bill, A2461, would would ban voting from any school that could not provide proper voter supervision or keep voters confined to a room accessible only by exterior door.

Both of those circumstances hold true at Haledon Public School, where the smaller of two gyms is occupied by voting booths every June and November.

“When they’re outside in the courtyard or the play area, walking to school or leaving the building, that’s where it becomes tricky,” Hernandez said. “On those days, we put extra teachers, extra eyes out there to ensure that the kids are going home with the right parents.”

Liesl Iza, who has a son attending Haledon Public School, said officials appear to be managing the situation well. There really is no better location for polling, she said.

“Perhaps it would be better if the students weren’t there, but given the situation the administrators and police do a good job of securing the premises and making it work,” she said.

search_result.title: Growing number of students seeking accommodations for SAT
search_result.text:
Deena Yellin

Staff Writer, @deenayellin

In 2015-16, the College Board received 160,000 requests

Now, most students with an IEP calling for test-taking modifications will automatically receive them

Applies to all tests administered by College Board: SAT, PSAT, SAT and AP exams

Student requests for extra time, more breaks or a quieter room when taking the SAT have doubled over the past five years, according to the College Board, which administers the test.

That upward trend for these requests — known as accommodations — is likely to continue as the number of children being diagnosed with a disability continues to grow and a new policy, which took effect Jan.1, now makes it easier for students to get an accommodations approval when taking the SAT.

High school guidance counselors and parents of disabled students across North Jersey say the change is long overdue and will help streamline the process for thousands who lack the resources to fight the denial of an accommodations request.

For years, parents and guidance counselors have complained about the difficulty of obtaining approval for modifications in taking the SAT, even if the student is already receiving similar supports in school because of a classified disability.

Robert Valli, supervisor of guidance at Cresskill High School, used to spend hours gathering and sending paperwork to the College Board in order to document a student's disability and need for accommodations. The student then had to wait several weeks for a response. "Sometimes the kids were frustrated because they couldn't take the test until they heard back," he said.

Now, under the new policy, most students with an individualized education plan (IEP) that includes modifications for test-taking will receive automatic approval for the same supports when taking the SAT, PSAT, SAT subject tests and AP exams, which are all administered by the College Board. The new policy does not apply to the ACT, which is administered by a different group.

"This cuts down on the paperwork and on the time," Valli said, adding that he's seen more students apply for the modifications in recent years. "Now the approval will be easier and simpler."

The new regulation comes as the number of requests to the board has soared, officials said:

In 2015-16, the board received approximately 160,000 requests;

In 2014-15, requests totaled 108,000;

In 2010-11, there were 80,000.

The vast majority — 85 percent — of the requests are approved.

"In New Jersey we have more students with IEP and 504 plans (a specified educational plan for students who have an impairment) than we had five years ago and definitely more than 10 years ago," said Dana Karas, president of the New Jersey School Counselor Association, who attributed the increase in accommodations requests in part to the surge in classified students. Because many students feel the adaptations can lead to higher SAT scores, there is an impetus to get an edge, she said, adding that higher scores can yield scholarship money and acceptance to better colleges.

Roughly 220,000 students in New Jersey have a special education classification, according to the New Jersey Department of Education. Guidance counselors at Bergenfield High School, Passaic High School, Emerson High School and the Northern Valley Regional High School District say the numbers of students requesting special accommodations on the college entrance exams are on the rise.

Making a difference

The ultimate goal is to level the playing field so that all students can prove themselves, said Heidi Cosmic-Godau, supervisor of guidance at West Milford High School. "You want students to have the accommodations that will help them demonstrate what their abilities are, so you want to eliminate the barriers," she said.

"For students with anxiety, the time limit really affects their ability to think. They are more worried about running out of time than doing their best. Some students don't even need the extended time, but it helps reduce their stress level."

For one Glen Rock High School graduate, taking the SAT with 100-percent extra time (eight hours in total) and additional breaks made all the difference, said his mother, who did not want to be identified. "The request was handled by a case manager for the child study team who did all the paperwork," said the mother. Her son, who suffers from severe dyslexia, "absolutely needed that time and those extra breaks," she said, adding that he's been very successful as a college student.

It was not always easy to secure such accommodations. Kristen Antone, 20, of Middletown had special support since elementary school due to processing issues and problems with visual motor perception, said her mother, Karen Antone. But when she applied for accommodations for the SAT, the College Board demanded a new evaluation proving her disability.

"At the time, my husband had just passed away and I didn't have $1,000 for an evaluation," Antone said. She appealed to the district, the College Board and various special needs groups for help but to no avail. Kristen had to take the SAT without accommodations and scored 60 points lower than required by the college of her choice.

She is currently an honors student at her second-choice college but believes she would have had a shot at getting into the college of her dreams had she been granted the accommodations. "It wasn't fair that if you had $1,000 you had a better chance of going to a good college than someone else," Antone said. "The new policy is how it should be."

Under the new policy, if the answer is "yes" to both "is the requested accommodations in the student's plan" and "has the student used the accommodations for school testing," the student is automatically eligible for the accommodations on the College Board exam. Once students are approved for the accommodations with the College Board, they don't need to reapply if they want to retest. Colleges are not notified if students utilize accommodations.

Reason for change

College Board spokeswoman Maria Alcon-Heraux said the new policy was made in response to educators, parents and students who requested that the board cut down on the red tape. "The process will further reduce confusion and uncertainty by aligning College Board accommodation with students' existing IEP, 504 plans and other formal school-based plans. All students should have access to the testing accommodations they need so they can show their best work on our assessments."

More students today are getting special services and accommodations because schools today are better at identifying issues early, said Betty Faber, a tutor for the past 17 years in Tenafly. Getting the extra help can make a world of a difference. "You can have a very bright kid who has poor processing delay or an auditory delay, and these kids can do very well if you give them extra accommodations."

The SAT can be a daunting exam for any student, but it's even worse for those who suffer from ADHD, dyslexia or other disabilities. "Classified students are already struggling. There's a lot of drama over taking tests," said Linda Leenstra, a special education advocate and special needs consultant based in Sussex County, who welcomes the loosened restrictions.

But some parents and experts are critical of anything that might make it easier for some students to gain an edge over their peers. Kate Robinson, a college consultant based in Wayne, agrees "100 percent there are going to be situations with students who should not be receiving accommodations."
