search_result.text:
MARÍA MÉNDEZ

Texas Tribune

Almost a year after Texas’ deadliest school shooting, state lawmakers ordered school districts to secure schools with armed officers and to train more staff to identify students who might need mental health support under legislation set to become law in September.

The new school safety law will grant the Texas Education Agency more authority to make sure schools have robust safety plans to respond to an active shooter – something about half of all Texas school districts lacked, according to a 2020 assessment report. Meanwhile, another law will allow schools to use school safety funds to employ unlicensed chaplains for mental health roles, a move some critics have said could allow religious activists to recruit in schools and further polarize school communities.

The renewed emphasis on school safety came in response to the shooting at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde last year. But despite the new measures, state lawmakers didn’t listen to Uvalde parents’ calls to pass legislation that would’ve raised the minimum age to buy an AR-style rifle from 18 to 21.

All in all, experts say many of the changes will bolster school safety, but some requirements, such as for armed officers, may be challenging for public schools to implement by the upcoming school year with limited funding and staffing constraints. The legislation does not punish schools for not having an armed guard at every school.

Here’s what you need to know about the changes lawmakers made to school safety in Texas.

What prompted these new laws?

Over a year ago, a teenage gunman entered Uvalde’s Robb Elementary School and killed 19 children and two teachers in what became Texas’ deadliest school shooting. Seventeen people also were injured.

Law enforcement didn’t breach the classrooms the gunman had taken over for more than an hour amid lapses in communication and leadership, according to investigations by state officials and journalists. A state committee report also found “systemic failures” and missed warning signs that the gunman might have been planning a violent attack.

In response, state leaders called for boosting schools’ physical security measures to protect them against intruders and addressing student mental health.

Not long after the shooting, some Texas officials, including U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, called for placing law enforcement officers at all schools, though some law enforcement leaders at the time noted it would be challenging to fully staff and pay for such a proposal.

What actions did state leaders take after the Uvalde shooting?

About a month after the shooting in Uvalde, Gov. Greg Abbott and state leaders channeled $100 million toward school safety initiatives, including silent panic alert technology that was mandated by the TEA to quickly alert police whenever there’s an intruder in a school.

Abbott also appointed a chief of school safety and security, a new TEA position, to serve schools and the Legislature as a security expert. He also ordered audits to see how effective schools are at detecting and stopping intruders.

In February, Abbott made school safety an emergency item for the regular legislative session, calling on state lawmakers to provide additional funding for school safety and mental health and to “use the newly created Chief of School Safety and Security to ensure compliance with all mandated school safety standards.”

What school safety changes did the Texas Legislature make?

Heeding Abbott’s call, state lawmakers passed House Bill 3. The broad legislation expands and reinforces several existing school safety efforts, like requiring mental health training for more school staff, and outlines more ways schools can use funding for school safety. The law will go into effect in September, but lawmakers gave schools some flexibility to meet the requirements for armed guards and staff mental health training.

Despite the renewed focus on school safety, state lawmakers largely ignored calls from Uvalde parents for more gun regulations. During this year’s regular session, the families pushed for a bill that would’ve raised the minimum age to buy an AR-style weapon from 18 to 21. The bill saw some traction in the Legislature, but it failed to pass along with several other proposed firearm safety measures.

HB 3 also creates a new safety and security department within the TEA to be led by Abbott’s appointed chief of school safety and security. That department will be tasked with monitoring school districts’ compliance with safety requirements, including the intruder detection audits ordered by Abbott. If a district fails to submit school safety information or address any concerns, the new law gives the commissioner of education the power to appoint a conservator to oversee the district’s school board and superintendent and correct the issues. The law says this corrective action would not apply to school districts that fail to have an armed officer at every school.

How will schools and the state work together to secure campuses?

The legislation also requires more cooperation between the TEA and the Texas School Safety Center, a research center at Texas State University tasked with collecting and sharing school safety information from schools and law enforcement.

The TEA and the center must work together to assess the security of school campuses at least once every four years, and set facility standards for districts at least once every five years. The legislation also directs the TEA commissioner to develop guidelines for districts to notify parents of “violent activity” that takes place or is investigated at the district, and orders the Texas School Safety Center to provide schools with resources they can hand over to parents on how to safely store their firearms.

In addition, school districts must provide the Texas Department of Public Safety and local emergency responders with maps of each school and let them conduct a walkthrough of school buildings. In counties with a population of less than 350,000 inhabitants, sheriffs also must conduct semiannual school safety meetings with local law enforcement officers, emergency responders and school leaders.

The legislation raises the amount districts receive each year for school safety expenses to $10 per student — an increase of $0.28 — and provides them with an additional $15,000 per campus.

Lawmakers also allocated $1.1 billion in the state budget for the TEA to award grants to help school districts pay for some school safety requirements, like silent panic alerts. School districts will first be able to apply for funds to help them meet minimum safety standards, according to the TEA. In a second cycle, grants will be offered to school districts so they can meet other identified safety needs, the agency said.

The new funding will likely not cover all the costs of implementing the new requirements, according to education associations and school safety experts. Placing an armed officer or guard at every school campus will be particularly expensive, they said.

“Everyone wants to do everything possible to keep students safe, but we are very concerned about our schools’ ability to meet all of the new requirements given the limited resources that are available,” said Brian Whitley, a spokesperson for the Texas Public Charter Schools Association. He noted that charter schools are particularly worried because they can’t levy taxes to help pay for school security upgrades, unlike traditional public school districts.

Will there be an armed police officer at every school?

The legislation directs school districts to have at least one armed officer at each campus during regular school hours. The officer must be a commissioned peace officer from the district’s own police department, a school resource officer from another law enforcement agency or a peace officer hired as a security officer.

Many school districts already hire some internal or external police officers, but they may have to resort to alternatives, such as arming school staff or hiring private security officers, to guard all school campuses.

Jacksonville Independent School District police Chief Bill Avera said his district has officers stationed at each of its schools. But Avera, who also serves as vice president of the Texas School Police Chiefs Association and as a member of the Texas School Safety Center’s board of directors, acknowledged other school districts could face challenges doing so.

In addition to paying for an officer’s salaries and benefits, school districts sometimes also have to take care of equipment costs, like paying for uniforms, gear and patrol vehicles, Avera said.

The Texas Association of School Boards estimates the cost of hiring a police officer for districts could range from $80,000 to $100,000 per year, said Joy Baskin, the associate executive director of policy and legal services for TASB.

And the pool for eligible officers is competitive amid a nationwide shortage of law enforcement job candidates, Avera said. His district, for example, has relied on retired police officers to staff its schools, he said.

“It takes a minute nowadays to hire a police officer,” he said. “There's a lot of background work. There's a lot of things that have to be reviewed and checked on to ensure that (officers) are qualified, and so it’ll be interesting with all the school districts looking for officers at basically the same time.”

Texas has more than a thousand traditional public school districts and almost 200 charter school operators or districts.

What happens if school districts can’t staff their schools with police officers?

The legislation doesn’t outline penalties for school districts that don’t meet the armed officer requirement, Baskin said.

If school districts can’t staff schools with armed peace officers because of financial or staffing constraints, the legislation allows for a school board to claim a “good cause exception.” Each school board will determine what these exceptions will look like locally and must outline an “alternative security standard with which the district is able to comply,” the TEA told The Texas Tribune.

According to the law, alternative plans can include allowing trained staff members to be armed. A new option in the school safety law approved this year is for districts to contract with a licensed private security firm that has personnel licensed to be armed, Avera said.

Districts can arm their staff members through the state-run school marshal program, which requires 80 hours of training and certification by the Texas Commission on Law Enforcement, or by setting their own policies — known as “Guardian Plans” — to designate specific individuals to carry firearms.

In a 2020 report from the Texas School Safety Center, 41% of the state’s more than one thousand school districts reported contracting school resource officers from other law enforcement agencies and 32% employed their own police officers, but about 70% of districts said they hired only between one and five police officers. About half of districts reported using nonlaw-enforcement security personnel, including 27.4% under Guardian Plans and 6% under the school marshal program.

In a similar 2022 report about charter school districts, 30.2% of almost 200 charter school operators in the state reported using nonlaw-enforcement security personnel, including 24.2% who hired private security.

Arming school staff could be less expensive than hiring police officers but still requires vetting and training under the school marshals program. The state pays for school marshal training, but that training is not always widely available, so school districts may still incur travel costs for their staff to be trained, said Craig Bessent, a school marshal in Wylie Independent School District, where he also serves as assistant superintendent of school operations.

“I wish we would have had more legislative help on that, but we didn’t, so we'll just see how it plays out,” said Bessent, who is also chair of the Texas School Safety Center’s board of directors.

In addition, finding school employees who want to be armed might be hard. In the past, they have been reluctant to do so. About a month after the Uvalde shooting, a survey showed that Texas teachers do not want to take a gun to school.

Given these constraints, Bessent said school districts are “scrambling” to figure out how to follow the legislation before it is expected to go into effect in September.

The TEA said it plans to provide additional guidance, including webinars with an overview of HB 3 and school safety-related funding, within the next few weeks.

Districts will likely work to meet the requirements as soon as possible, Baskin said, but it may take some time.

“I think many districts will want to stay as closely aligned to the statute as possible. In part because they do want to provide the best possible safety for students, but also in part because they would not want to be out of sync with the legal requirements if there were an emergency event,” she said.

State Rep. Dustin Burrows, the Republican from Lubbock who authored the bill, did not respond to a request for comment on the rollout of the requirement.

What are the rules around guns on campuses?

Schools are generally considered gun-free zones under federal and state laws except in certain circumstances, including in the case of police officers, school marshals and individuals authorized by the school district to carry guns.

A 1990 federal law bans firearms on school property or within 1,000 feet of public and private schools, but the law makes exceptions for law enforcement and individuals licensed to carry. Other exceptions in federal law include if the gun is not loaded and is locked away or if the individual has been authorized to carry a gun by the district.

Texas also generally bans guns where school-sponsored activities take place, unless an individual is exempted. HB 3 clarifies that individuals allowed to carry firearms at schools but who aren’t law enforcement officers can’t carry out routine law enforcement duties unless there is an emergency that poses a serious threat of injury or death.

How will new Texas laws address student mental health?

Every school staff member who regularly interacts with students will be required to take evidence-based mental health training designed to help school staff identify signs that a student may need mental health support, which Avera said can be crucial to preventing violence.

The legislation allows school districts to stagger the training of staff to meet the requirement by the 2028-2029 school year, but Baskin said districts may work to complete the requirement sooner amid a renewed focus on student mental health, also spurred by the pandemic.

School districts can be reimbursed by TEA for the costs of providing this training to employees, according to legislation, but schools and mental health advocates did not get a dedicated funding stream for mental health. Many expressed worries that meeting the other school safety requirements will take up most of the available funding.

The Legislature also passed a bill this session that gives schools the option to use school safety funds to pay for unlicensed chaplains to work in mental health roles. Volunteer chaplains will also be allowed in schools. Policies for chaplains in schools will be up to local school boards. Parental consent is required for school-related mental health services, including chaplains, the TEA said.

And lawmakers boosted funding to the Texas Child Health Access Through Telemedicine program, which connects school districts with mental health professionals who can help identify student behavioral needs and help provide access to those services. The program is expected to receive $140 million for the next two years.

search_result.title: Here's how Savannah could spend its $55 million in COVID relief ...
search_result.text:
Savannah City Manager Jay Melder considers federal American Rescue Plan funds "a one-time opportunity for cities to make down payments and investments and make progress in key areas where we need to go forward."

On Tuesday, Melder laid out his recommendations on how to best leverage Savannah's $55 million share of the COVID-19 relief funds to benefit the community.

“When I took the job on Sept. 10, I told mayor and council that I wanted to be able to provide an ARPA list and that my priorities would be that ARPA be spent and be seen in the communities,” Melder said Tuesday during the first day of the city’s two day Fiscal Year 2022 budget retreat, which was held at the Savannah Civic Center.

"That's what we've been able to do."

Melder's plan addresses a range of needs, from affordable housing and recreation to stormwater drainage and public safety. The federal government dictates how the city can use the monies, but the guidelines are broad: ARPA funds can be used for public health expenditures; to address negative economic impacts caused by the pandemic; to replace lost public sector revenue; to provide premium pay for essential workers; or by investing in water, sewer and broadband infrastructure.

About the American Rescue Plan Act Signed into law in March by President Joe Biden, the American Rescue Plan Act provided more than $350 billion in federal funding to local city and county governments across the country in an effort to support COVID-19 response efforts, to replace lost revenue and to keep local economies afloat.

More:Rep. Carter voted no on Biden's infrastructure package, calling it a 'trojan horse'

More:Developer: New vision for fairgrounds to be a boost for all of Savannah

Here are Melder's ARPA allocation recommendations:

Housing and homelessness

A total of $10.6 million of the total funding would be allocated toward the city’s efforts to provide more affordable housing and tackle the growing issues of homelessness in the city.

The Housing Savannah Plan would receive $7 million, which Melder said was an unprecedented investment by the city to the Housing Savannah Trust Fund, which council created in 2011.

More:Housing Savannah Task Force aims to help 15,000 households by 2032. Here's what comes next.

“This is a down payment on what the Housing Savannah Plan called for to meet the needs of more than 21,000 residents who are housing insecure in Savannah,” he said.

Another $500,000 is being proposed for homelessness support service grants and an additional $3.1 million in HUD ARPA funds will be put to use for things such as public supportive housing and critical emergency housing.

Savannah Safe

Various public safety projects, which would extend outside of just the police and fire departments, would receive $17.4 million of the total funding.

Melder is recommending $1 million be used for grants for community partners, grassroots organizations and nonprofits who are working to end gun violence; another $80,000 would be put toward the newly relaunched Police Athletic Program

A total of $6.4 million would be used for public safety facilities, to include a new joint public safety fire and police substation in the New Hampstead area. That funding would also give the city the flexibility to later address other public safety facilities, many of which the city leases, Melder said.

More:City of Savannah, Johnson defend actions as First Amendment lawsuit ends with injunction

“We need funding dollars to be able to make facility investments that are needed in order to meet service needs and be better stewards of our taxpayer dollars,” he said.

The Savannah Police Department headquarters at the corner of Habersham Street and Oglethorpe Avenue could also get a facelift. The plan allocates $2.5 million for renovations.

Melder's recommendations also call for $4.5 million for priority fire apparatus. A firefighting apparatus is any vehicle that has been customized for use during firefighting operations, which Melder said is extremely expensive but also extremely important in order for the Savannah Fire Department to continue operating at its current level.

Another $3 million is being proposed for a city-owned shopping center at 37th Street and Waters Avenue. While in the long run Melder believes the best use for the site would be a grocery store, he is currently proposing that the site become the hub for the city’s Office of Neighborhood Safety and Engagement.

Back to basics

Just over $14 million of the funding would be used for basic infrastructure. Melder is recommending $4.8 million for stormwater ditch maintenance, which he said is a city-wide issue.

Additionally, $600,000 would be allocated for stormwater maintenance; lane maintenance and enhanced tree pruning would receive $1.2 million; and revenue loss recovery, $1.7 million.

A litter prevention and collection program would receive $1 million and about $300,000 would go toward two new knuckle boom trucks, which are used to collect yard and bulk items, bringing the city’s fleet to four. That allocation would also cover staff needed to support the additional operations. About $350,000 would be put toward recycling program equipment, including trucks and additional staff.

Stormwater meter modernization would see just over $4.3 million. Currently the city is several cycles behind in its water meter billing. One reason is because it’s "incredibly tedious" work to read meters by hand across the district, Melder said.

“This investment brings Savannah and this program a little bit farther into the 21st century by investing in new technology that doesn't require an actual physical reading but that reading is automatically delivered from the machine to the billing department,” he said, adding that the budget also includes complementary investments for water meter staff to help get the service back on track.

City Hall notebook:More than $4 million in contracts approved by Savannah City Council

Neighborhoods and people

Melder is proposing that just under $16 million be invested in Savannah's neighborhoods and households. The United Way of the Coastal Empire would receive a $1 million contribution and $1.45 million in community partnerships contributions.

Family support initiatives would receive $500,000 and the Early Childhood Learning Center planned for the east side would be allocated $1 million. Approximately $6 million in SPLOST funds are earmarked for construction of the learning center, which voters approved in 2019, with equal amounts coming from both the City of Savannah and Chatham County.

More:Savannah State formally welcomes 14th president during investiture ceremony

On the southside $4 million would be put towards a new community center. Another $4 million would go toward recreation projects across the city including several projects in Daffin Park such as overhauling the dog park and resurfacing basketball and tennis courts.

Another $4 million would go toward continuing Tide to Town, which consists of almost 30 miles of protected walking and bicycling trails throughout Savannah.

"It's a a wonderful asset that really can improve connectivity and also improve transportation options for people across the city," Melder said of the trail network.

The ARPA funding is the backbone of the city's fiscal year 2022 budget, Melder said.

"I think it makes this a very, very exciting budget, but what also makes this very, very exciting budget is that we've had a stronger than expected economy," he told council.

"And so we don't have to spend ARPA on paying ourselves back or our reserves back. We can spend all of ARPA on things that are going to benefit our community. So we're really pleased to be in that position."

Katie Nussbaum is the city and county government reporter for the Savannah Morning News. Contact her at knussbaum@savannahnow.com. Twitter: KnussSMN

search_result.title: El Paso to use $84 million of CARES Act funds to boost COVID-19 ...
search_result.text:
The majority of federal dollars the city of El Paso received through the CARES Act will be used to expand COVID-19 testing.

The El Paso City Council unanimously voted Tuesday to authorize City Manager Tommy Gonzalez to use $119 million in federal funds from the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act on various programs that will roll out between now and the end of the year.

Of that money, the council approved spending the bulk — $84.2 million — on "public health and safety response," which includes expanding testing and efforts to educate the public about proper safety practices as businesses and workplaces reopen.

The nearly $2 trillion CARES Act, which Congress passed late March, included individual stimulus checks, in addition to billions of dollars in federal aid for state and local governments. CARES funds can only be used for COVID-19 expenses cities made between March 1 and Dec. 30 that were not included in their budget.

The city of El Paso is preparing for "possible additional waves of outbreaks, the surge at our hospitals or possible surges, as well as potential future shelter-in-place (orders)," Nicole Cote, director of the Office of Management and Budget, told the council during a Monday work session.

By the end of June, city health officials hope to test 5% of the county's population, El Paso Fire Chief Mario D'Agostino said Monday. The city aims to test 2% of the population by this week's end.

Stay on top of the latest COVID-19 news:Click here to subscribe to elpasotimes.com.

City working to expand COVID-19 testing partnerships

The El Paso Department of Public Health is partnering with local school districts to open test sites at district facilities. Together, those sites will be able to test up to 1,000 people a day, D'Agostino said.

The city is also working to launch a public-private partnership with CVS Pharmacy to open drive-thru COVID-19 test sites at select stores, similar to the partnership unveiled with Walmart last week, in addition to partnering with University Medical Center of El Paso to increase testing in rural parts of the county.

More:Escobar says El Paso lags in coronavirus testing, warns minority community vulnerable

CARES funds will reimburse the University of Texas at El Paso for its assistance testing COVID-19 samples from the city's drive-thru test sites, which D'Agostino said will enable the El Paso Department of Public Health Laboratory to process up to 500 samples in an 8-hour period.

The money will cover the hiring of additional public health workers to assist with contract tracing, which involves identifying those who have come in contact with an infected person.

It will help expand antibody testing to determine how many El Pasoans were previously infected with the virus without knowing it. Antibody testing for first responders and health care workers began May 4, city spokeswoman Laura Cruz Acosta said.

In addition to boosting testing, CARES funds will support city efforts to train local businesses and workplaces on proper disinfection and social distancing practices so El Paso can "get back into an opening phase that's responsible," D'Agostino said. That includes ensuring businesses have sufficient personal protective equipment for employees, such as face masks and gloves.

The federal funds will also help El Paso prepare for the upcoming flu season, which can already strain hospitals. If the county experiences a resurgence of COVID-19 cases this winter, coronavirus patients paired with flu patients could overwhelm hospitals. To mitigate this, the city plans to offer flu vaccinations at its COVID-19 test sites with the goal of immunizing "everyone" against the flu, D'Agostino said.

CARES funds to help with community and economic recovery

The council approved spending the remaining $34.8 million of CARES funds on community and economic assistance programs.

Officials will allocate $16.4 million for "community response and recovery programs" and $18.4 million for "economic response and recovery programs."

More:COVID-19 layoffs: El Paso workers, businesspeople struggle with new economic realities

The $16.4 million will be used, in part, for rental, mortgage and utility assistance, in addition to supporting food banks and rehousing programs for residents who have been displaced. These programs will be enhanced by a $4.1 million federal Community Development Block Grant and $500,000 federal Emergency Shelter/Solutions Grant.

The $18.4 million will help expand city grant programs for small business owners seeking assistance with rent, utilities, supplies and inventory, and to help businesses access personal protective equipment and technology needed for remote work.

Nicole Ferrini, the city's chief resilience officer, emphasized during Tuesday's council meeting that the city will not administer any of the CARES funds for community recovery programs, but instead direct the monies to local service providers.

"We are a pass-through for federal funds," Ferrini said of the city's role in distributing CARES funds.

The next step, following council's approval of the overall funding allocations, is to notify community agencies and front-line service providers of the available community recovery funds they can apply for, Ferrini said. The city council will give the final approval to organizations city staff selects to receive parts of the $16.4 million.

Community leaders call for creation of Fund for Common Good

Nearly 20 people addressed the council during public comment Tuesday to request the council set aside at least $12 million of CARES funds for a Fund for the Common Good for immigrant households.

The CARES Act excluded unauthorized immigrants as well as their U.S. citizen or legal immigrant spouses and children from receiving stimulus checks, small business loans, paid leave and unemployment insurance benefits.

Melissa Lopez, the executive director of Diocesan Migrant & Refugee Services, Inc., estimated 26,000 families and 54,000 individuals in El Paso were excluded from this aid.

"Providing cash assistance is best because every single family's needs are going to be different," Lopez said of her support for the Fund for the Common Good.

The El Paso state legislative delegation also sent council members a letter Monday stating its support for such a fund, which reads many of those excluded "work in essential sectors hit hardest by the pandemic, such as hospitality and food service."

Following public comment the city manager stated organizations that support El Paso's immigrant community would not be not be excluded from receiving community recovery CARES Act funds.

"We are not turning anyone away," Gonzalez said.

Molly Smith may be reached at 915-546-6413; mksmith@elpasotimes.com; @smithmollyk on Twitter.

search_result.title: Noblesville shooting raises questions about safety in Indiana schools
search_result.text:
Two weeks ago, all the "what if" conversations Hoosiers have been having since a devastating shooting in Parkland, Fla., came into terrifying focus.

A 13-year-old walked into a science classroom at Noblesville West Middle School with two hand guns and opened fire, police say.

Communities throughout Indiana — and the country — that were re-examining the safety of their schools and calling on those in positions of power to do more had one more reason to call for action.

Harden school security. Provide more support. Increase funding. Strengthen gun laws. Arm teachers.

Before the Noblesville shooting, such calls were often met with a reassurance that Indiana was already doing more than most.

State leaders used the days and weeks following the Feb. 14 massacre at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School to highlight the state’s school safety grant program, its safety academy and existing requirements that school districts have a trained safety specialist and up-to-date safety plan in place.

Too late:Noblesville parents wanted more security. Then a school shooting happened.

Fighting for his job:Brownsburg teacher says transgender name policy for students goes against his religious beliefs

Political answers? Get the latest political news on education and other key issues from IndyStar's Hoosier Politics newsletter.

Last month, lawmakers passed a school safety bill that boosted the grant fund by $5 million and added a requirement that the Department of Education audit all safety plans this year. Previously, it had randomly selected around 60 to review each year.

Then, Noblesville happened.

Seventh-grader Ella Whistler was shot seven times and will face a long road to recovery. Science teacher Jason Seaman was also shot as he intervened to stop the shooting.

Everyone, from parents and teachers to law enforcement, agrees it could have been much worse.

So, how well did the school’s safety plan work? How integral were the $120,000 in state school safety grant funds that Noblesville had received since 2014?

We don’t know.

State law exempts safety plans from public disclosure.

And the millions of public dollars funneled to schools for safety initiatives? Those, too, are exempt. The Department of Homeland Security, which administers the grant program, has released the award amounts given to districts each year but nothing more.

In response to public records requests for details about how Noblesville spent its safety grant dollars, DHS said: “Details about specific applications, budgets, approvals and plans for individual school districts are withheld from public disclosure.”

State officials say they don't want would-be bad actors to know the details of schools' safety plans, response procedures and what deterrents might already be in place.

Still, communities are shaken. Kids are afraid.

Everyone is looking for answers that most experts agree may not exist. It’s impossible to eliminate all instances of school violence, though there are ways to mitigate risk.

“It’s a very complex issue,” said John Shales, co-founder of BluePoint Alert Solutions, which makes emergency response systems for schools. “We're going to learn a lot that makes it better for our communities.

“But can we get to a point of preventing all of them? I’d love to get there, but it seems like it’s a pretty tall mountain to get over at the moment.”

Not only is there likely no foolproof way to prevent a student — or anyone else, for that matter — from bringing a gun into a school, but it can be difficult to know how much schools are doing to prevent such incidents.

"There is no time to waste"

While anyone who works in education will say that school safety is a constant focus, public conversations about the topic tend to be cyclical. They bubble up in the immediate aftermath of school shootings and then quiet down in the days and weeks that follow.

Those conversations started again in February, after the Parkland shooting that left 17 dead. Noblesville was one of many communities having those conversations.

In response, the district held a public forum to seek input.

At the same time, Indiana's lawmakers began touting the many things the state already does to ensure it has safe schools: the safety plans, and specialists. The free training.

On March 9, Gov. Eric Holcomb sent a leader to legislative leaders, commending Indiana's leadership on school safety and requesting another $5 million be added to the state's $10 million school safety grant fund.

"There is no time to waste," he wrote in the letter's close.

Less than three months later, police say a 13-year-old student entered Noblesville West Middle School armed and opened fire in his classroom. Court documents indicate the suspect used a .22-caliber handgun in the shooting and also was in possession of a .45-caliber handgun and a knife.

Jason Seaman, a seventh-grade science teacher, was shot three times and is credited with helping to stop the attack. He was released from the hospital the following day.

Ella Whistler, 13, was shot seven times and suffered broken bones to her neck, ribs and jaw, collapsed lungs and a severed vertebral vein, her family said this week in a written statement. She remains hospitalized in "stable" condition.

What prompted the shooting and exactly what occurred in the classroom are still unclear. Authorities have released few details.

One prominent lawmaker is already calling on the state do to more. House Minority Leader Terry Goodin, D-Seymour, issued a letter this week calling on the General Assembly to add a permanent school safety commission to the legislature’s roster of summer study groups.

“Recently the fears of every Hoosier parent, teacher, student and school administrator were realized when an active shooter incident happened in Indiana,” Goodin wrote in the letter addressed to the legislature. “This should be a wakeup call for the leaders of Indiana to do more.

“Even though our state is on the leading edge in the nation in regards to School Safety, we still need to do more.”

Gregg Doyel: As Noblesville hero Jason Seaman heals, a community heals with him

Stepping up:Meet a student who helped raise $100K for Jason Seaman after shooting

At a news conference in the shooting's aftermath, Holcomb pledged to provide whatever resources are needed but also argued that the state’s focus on school safety plans and resources is working. In fact, he said it played a key role in preventing additional carnage in Noblesville, though he declined to provide details.

“It is making a difference,” he said of the state’s school safety funding. “It did today. I am convinced it saved lives.”

How is unclear, though. The amount that schools receive from the grant program is public — Noblesville has received more than $120,000 since 2014 — but what they do with it is not.

Officials with Noblesville Schools declined to provide details about its safety plan or how it spent that grant money, but said it's active shooter response system made a difference at West Middle School. The district uses a system called ALICE, which stands for Alert, Lockdown, Inform, Counter, Evacuate.

"Our ALICE system and the related training/practice in particular is a key part of why we did not have a worse outcome on May 25," said Marnie Cooke, spokesperson for the district.

Cooke said the district expects to announce recommendations for safety enhancements next week.

Looking for a school safety model

Even before the incident in Noblesville, worried parents across the country were looking to another Indiana school for answers.

It's been almost five years since Southwestern High School near Shelbyville unveiled an extreme active shooter defense system that had some calling it the "safest school in America." The system is designed to thwart an active shooter by using cameras with a direct feed to the county sheriff's office, panic buttons for teachers and smoke cannons in hallways.

But, despite continued concerns over school shootings, it remains an anomaly.

Juvenile law:After Noblesville shooting, Indiana joins other states grappling with juvenile laws

Plea for patience:Attorney for Noblesville school shooting suspect asks for 'patience and privacy'

There are several likely reasons. First and foremost: the cost.

Five years ago, the system had a $400,000 price tag. And that's for a relatively small school.

Scaled up for the largest high school in the state — the 1-million-square-foot Carmel High School — for example, "it would cost millions," said Chuck McCormick, a Partner Alliance for School Safety steering committee member.

Even at $400,000, equipping every school in the state with such a system would cost in the realm of $750 million.

For perspective, the state increased school safety funding by $5 million. Typically, the state spends about $10 million per year, which is in the form of matching grant funds typically used to hire school resource officers — police officers who work in schools — and safety equipment.

Southwestern High School received two matching grants from the state to install the system, and the security system provider, Net Talon, paid the difference, said Don Jones, president of the Virginia company.

Not every school has those opportunities and such systems might not make sense in all school settings.

4 reasons:Why all schools aren't like the 'safest school in America'

Reflections on Noblesville school shooting:Our schools shouldn't be war zones

Another solution many have been calling for in the wake of the Noblesville incident is metal detectors at school entrances.

Relatively few schools actually use metal detectors on a regular basis. Schools may start looking more closely at them after Noblesville, but many school officials say they’re just not practical in all cases.

"Think about the reality of having metal detectors at a school the size of 4,200 students like Ben Davis," said Jeff Butts, superintendent of Wayne Township Schools. Wayne is home to Ben Davis High School, one of the largest in the state. "The number of resources that would take … we struggle now to fill custodial positions, bus drivers, those types of things."

The manpower needed to staff the entrances, though, and training to properly use metal detectors is the least of Butts' concerns.

"What I'm concerned about is if we put metal detectors at our entrances … think of having all of our students standing in one great big group outside the school," he said. "That's the perfect location for something very bad to happen, as opposed to getting all the students in the school house and getting them to their classrooms."

"Everyone's kind of looking for a magic wand"

Not everyone agrees that hardening schools is the best solution to prevent shootings, either.

Many advocacy groups are clamoring for tighter gun laws with hopes that such approaches would keep guns out of schools and lessen the need for buttoning up schools.

Beth Sprunger is a Hamilton County parent of an 8-year-old and 4-year-old. She’s also a leader of the Indiana chapter of Moms Demand Action, a group that advocates for changes to state and national gun laws. Moms Demand Action will continue to focus its efforts, Sprunger said, on strengthening gun laws, rather than hardening school buildings.

Other groups, such as the National Rifle Association, have called for more armed guards in schools or even arming teachers. Indiana is one of several states that already allows for arming teachers or administrators, at the discretion of individual school boards.

Sprunger said she has friends with kids in Nobesville schools. There's been a lot of outcry, she said, for metal detectors and other "target hardening" techniques in the days since the shooting there. Still, she's not convinced that's the answer.

"The research is still out on whether or not those techniques will actually work or not," she said. "Also, I'm not sure how that will effect the learning environments for those students."

Bill Payne is CEO of Fanning Howey, an architecture and engineering firm specializing in the design of learning environments with offices in Indiana and Ohio, said safety is a part of every school design these days but it needs to be balanced with the core function of schools.

"We all want to make school buildings safer, but at the same time we don’t want to lose the nurturing environment we want our students to learn in," Payne said. "Those two seem like they could be in conflict at times."

Even with unlimited resources, he said it's unlikely schools could prevent 100 percent of attacks.

It’s a harsh reality. But it’s the one that David Woodward, the Indiana Department of Education's director of school building security, lives in.

"Everyone's kind of looking for a magic wand," Woodward said. "School safety has to be a comprehensive approach."

He said that should include infrastructure, training for students and staff, mental health supports and more.

"It can’t just be SROs (school resource officers), equipment for target hardening, mental health," he said. "It has to be all of these things done well, and it has to result in a well-trained staff and student body."

Woodward said that most schools are already doing some combination of these things. Much of it is outlined in the private safety plans. Whether those plans are robust enough, though, is a judgment left to the department. The privacy of the security plans is a safety mechanism, too, Woodward said.

"Let's say you’re someone who wants to do harm to someone else," he said. "It's not good that the person who would do harm knows what all of your responses would be."

Those plans are audited by the Department of Education, but not every year. The department randomly selects roughly 60 districts to audit each year.

That will change. New legislation, passed in the wake of Parkland, will require the department to audit all schools (though the results will also be withheld from the public).

So how can students, teachers and parents evaluate how well their schools are doing on safety? How can the public evaluate if millions of taxpayer dollars dedicated to safety grants are being well spent?

Ask questions, Woodward said. Without asking for details, parents can ask administrators for general information about a school's approach to safety, training, school climate and more.

“Have those conversations with school administrators,” he said. “They want to do the best job they possible can.”

Fayetteville is trying to stretch the once-in-a-lifetime funding it received from the federal government, and Assistant City Manager Adam Lindsay has a plan: use these restricted dollars to pay for the city’s needs and free up unrestricted dollars to go after other federal grants.

Lindsay called the American Rescue Plan Act “unprecedented” during the Fayetteville City Council work session on Monday.

“The opportunities and needs we have are aligned in a way that we will probably never see again in our lifetimes,” he said. “If we spend the dollars in a strategic way.”

Fayetteville will receive around $40.4 million in American Rescue Plan Act funds in two installments: one in May 2021 and one in May 2022. It must allocate the money by December 2024 and spend it by December 2026.

That is a tight timeline, especially if the city were to start projects with ARP funds. Instead, Lindsay is suggesting using the federal dollars to fund projects that the city has already identified, or even started. That way the city can dedicate previously allocated money to pay for federal grants.

"Two million can turn into 10 million dollars,” Lindsay said.

The City Council unanimously supported implementing this strategic plan for its ARP funds.

Currently, the city is considering allocating $15 million of its ARP funds as follows:

$500,000 for business assistance loans

$500,000 for commercial corridors grants

$1 million for childcare and daycare assistance

$1 million for small business development grants

$2 million for small business retention grants

$4 million for a housing trust fund for affordable housing

$1 million for a community hub

$1.3 million for first floor renovations of City Hall

$150,000 for picnic shelter replacements and refurbishments

$650,000 for Rosemary Drive drainage improvements

$2.75 million for Tryon Drive drainage improvements

$150,000 for American Disabilities Act compliance issues

$5 million for administrative initiatives

Lindsay added that the city is “easily” looking at more than $150 million in projects.

Flooding fixes

One potential project that will cost millions of dollars is flooding mitigation across the city. The city has commissioned several watershed studies to determine the areas of greatest need and the best options for fixing them.

City staff on Monday requested $8.8 million to lessen flooding effects at Locks Creek. However, this money only addresses 25-year storm events (Hurricane Matthew was a 500-year storm, and Hurricane Florence was a 1,000-year storm) and doesn’t completely prevent flooding.

Mayor Mitch Colvin called this idea a “partial fix” that would still allow the flooding of homes.

Sheila Thomas-Abat, public services director, replied that any plan to try to address flooding in Locks Creek was “fighting nature” because it was in a flood plain. The Federal Emergency Management Agency does not qualify Locks Creek as a flood plain, but the city is submitting documentation to change that designation.

Thomas-Abat added that if the area had been a registered flood plain, then there would have been more restrictions about building homes there.

“This is the most dangerous element,” said Mayor Pro Tem Kathy Jensen. “It always wins.”

In December, the City Council allocated $150 million for infrastructure improvements to help mitigate flooding. City staff requested $8.8 million on Monday, will request $12 million in a few months, and is planning to request even more next year.

City staff added that addressing flooding at all watersheds in the city could cost around $500 million.

That means that residents will soon see a rate increase, although Thomas-Abat did not specify the amount.

“We don’t want to raise fees and we don’t want to raise taxes, but sometimes it’s necessary,” said Councilman Larry Wright.

Capital and technology improvement plans

Using funds the city currently has, city staff also presented projects that could be feasible for the budgets of fiscal years 2023 to 2027.

The capital projects include:

$22.7 million for a consolidated car rental facility; general aviation hangar development; perimeter road paving and fencing replacement; and taxiway pavement and lighting rehabilitation at the airport.

$3.6 million for a commercial corridor revitalization program; a day resource center and emergency shelter; and support infrastructure for redevelopment area.

$3.3 million for ADA compliance fixes; building maintenance; finance remodeling; operations center feasibility study; parking lot resurfacing and Ramsey Street pump station replacement.

$23.6 million for Blounts Creek Trail; Cape Fear River Park; Cape Fear River trail and botanical garden extension; Mable C. Smith Park improvements; Makerspace; Martin Luther King Jr. Park; McArthur Sports Field Complex; picnic shelter replacements and refurbishing; playground repairs and refurbishing; Senior Center East and Sherwood Park Recreation Center.

$550,000 for 911 dispatch consoles and temporary fire station #18.

$48.75 million for watershed studies, drainage assistance program, spot repair program and easements project management.

$1.1 million for Grove Street facility improvements, shelters and benches, sidewalks and ADA accessibility.

$46.1 million for Blanton Road extension; bridge preservation program; College Lakes dam; dam safety and preservation program; downtown streetscape; Hinsdale Road reconstruction; intersection improvements; Mirror Lake Drive dam; multi-use lanes; municipal agreements with the North Carolina Department of Transportation; pavement preservation program; sidewalk improvements and thoroughfare street lighting.

The technology projects include:

$6.8 million for security and infrastructure, including public safety camera replacements.

$483,000 for business intelligence and data analysis.

$4.9 million for software services, including body camera upgrades, Taser replacements, rapid DNA technology and a drone.

$175,000 for city wireless expansion project.

However, there is still $151.2 million in projects that city staff did not include in their capital and technology improvement plans for the next five years. These include public safety facilities; street, sidewalk and trail enhancements; an indoor aquatic center; phase two of City Hall renovations; and a cycling and derby park.

Councilman Antonio Jones said that he would also like to add to the list of potential projects a green space in the Murchison Road corridor near Shaw Road.

Overall, the city will be able to pay for many projects, thanks to Lindsay’s strategy with ARP funds. Overall, Lindsay's strategy allows for the city to pay for any projects with ARP funds.

“We are multiplying the benefit to our citizens if we use those funds to cover the costs with projects that we have identified are eligible and use the grant matching potential from the money we’ve freed up,” said Kelly Olivera, budget and evaluation director.

CLIFTON — The city has been awarded a $455,000 federal grant it wants to use to get a third ambulance on its streets permanently.

The SAFER grant, or Staffing for Adequate Fire and Emergency Response, which will be paid out over three years, can only be used to add personnel to the fire department, said city Manager Nick Villano.

The grant will be enough to hire four firefighters who "can operate the third ambulance 100 percent," Villano said.

When he announced the grant, 9th District Democrat Congressman Bill Pascrell, Jr., said the additional hires will bring the department's staffing to the highest in 25 years.

“This award, and others, is pivotal to making sure that our communities can retain and expand their fire services,” Pascrell said.

More:Juveniles arrested in Paterson, Clifton killings likely to be tried as adults, experts say

More:First woman firefighter to be promoted to lieutenant in Clifton

Firefighters in Clifton also serve as emergency medical technicians, and due to the low staffing, officials said, it has been difficult to operate a third and much-needed full time ambulance. When the two full time ambulances are out on calls, additional calls are responded to through a mutual aid agreement with neighboring departments.

Clifton also received a $1.73 million SAFER grant in 2015.

The 2015 grant allowed for the restoration of 11 department positions cut in 2009 to trim the budget.

The recent grant will bring the department to 143 firefighters, one short of the highest staffing level.

"This is the grant we were waiting for," Clifton Mayor James Anzaldi said. "The additional manpower should bring us to our goal."

Councilmen Peter Eagler and Bill Gibson were more guarded in their response.

"Hiring four firefighters is great and on paper looks good and some will say this will allow us to implement the third ambulance, but it's the minimum manpower per shift that is the important fact," Gibson said.

Chief Kevin McCarthy agreed with Gibson's analysis. In order for three ambulances to be in rotation, the department must have 28 firefighters working each shift, he said.

A typical shift consists of seven engines each staffed with three firefighters, one deputy chief and two medical technicians per ambulance.

When the number drops below 28 the third ambulance is taken out of rotation.

There are four 24-hour shifts, McCarthy said, and even with 143 firefighters, it's not guaranteed there will be 28 firefighters on duty each shift depending on retirements, sick days and vacation time.

The four additional firefighters will improve the level of service and safety for the city's residents and firefighters, McCarthy said.

The department, in the midst of hiring, will now hire 10 rather than six. The Oct. 1 new hires will be ready to hit the streets in January following training.

"It is a win for us," Eagler said. "It is after all government money coming back to us and it is better if it comes to Clifton."

He added that $455,000 is almost a full tax point. To the average homeowner that is about $17 per year they stand to save because of the grant.

It is one of many grants that Pascrell, who co-chairs the House Fire Services Caucus, has procured for the city.

Between 2011 and 2014, the Clifton Fire Department has received just under $3.9 million through the Assistance to Firefighter grants and the SAFER programs.

search_result.title: Commissioner Sokol shares ways to improve public safety
search_result.text:
Two candidates are running for Montgomery County Commission, District 8, which covers a portion of Fort Campbell, then from Fort Campbell to Allen Road, and from the state line to Tiny Town Road,

Ron Sokol has represented District 8 since 2002. He chairs the Jail and Juvenile Committee, Building and Codes Committee and Beer Board. Sokol holds an associate's in criminal justice from the University of Kentucky and a bachelor's in public administration from Austin Peay State University. He is a retired first sergeant from the U.S. Army, served as a Montgomery County magistrate and was a Tennessee parole officer before retiring.

Tangi Smith is a 10-year resident of the district, an Army veteran and a military spouse.

Sokol, a Republican, responded to Leaf-Chronicle questions on these key issues. Smith, a Democrat, declined to answer and didn't provide a photograph.

Schools

What should the county do to address ongoing school growth needs?

Sokol: I and other commissioners have been concerned over school growth issues for some time and student populations per each school zone. However, all decisions of when, where and type of new school construction is solely made by the Clarksville-Montgomery County School Board. The commission can only approve funding requests as presented by the CMCSS. So far all funding requests, whether for construction, equipment or school buses, have been approved. We have also enabled funding through a private act allowing revenue to be generated off the vehicle renewal fees and would certainly look at any other sources of revenue allowed by state laws.

Downtown

What should the county’s role be in downtown Clarksville revitalization?

Sokol: Montgomery County’s role in the downtown revitalization is to encourage private enterprises to come in and create new neighborhoods and commercial districts through incentives and special tax considerations. An example is the Commons park downtown, which became an incentive for new construction. Austin Peay State University is also making an effort to expand their campus further downtown. This enterprise resulted in $167 million in property transactions and increased tax revenues on properties that were underutilized or vacant for years. Along with easing construction restrictions and other burdensome rules is inviting business to come back to the center of Clarksville.

Public safety

How should we address the increasing need for funding for law enforcement, EMS and fire protection?

Sokol: We have to support public safety. Of course Montgomery County would have to continue funding any requests but also look for other sources of revenues like grants, pilot programs, and contracts with other agencies, federal and state. One way to increase dollar efficiency is to reduce the amount of lost court costs and fees, look for better health care and provided services contracts for the sheriff’s office and EMS. Other than county allocations, grants and funded training programs should be continually looked for. Fire protection at this point is voluntary, but a regular department would have to be created in the future when it can be properly supported. Like all public services, increasing taxes would be the only way to increase funding.

FOR MORE

The Montgomery County election is Aug. 2.

Former U.S. House candidate Scott Walker is a Democrat once again.

The most controversial figure in Delaware politics left the Republican Party behind this week as he prepares for another bid for office in 2020 — possibly even the highest in the land.

"I'm going to run for president, or at least try," the 67-year-old Milford resident said Friday. "And if I don't do well, I'll come back and run for U.S. Senate or maybe governor."

Walker says he's plotting a presidential push in New Hampshire, the second party contest in the nation every four years, where he will need to gain ground on Democratic hopefuls like former vice president and fellow Delaware resident Joe Biden.

The Granite State primary will be held no later than Feb. 11, 2020, giving Walker plenty of time to file as a candidate for statewide office in Delaware if things don't work out.

Prep for the polls: See who is running for president and compare where they stand on key issues in our Voter Guide

"The odds of me getting the backing I need are infinitesimal," Walker said, adding that if Michael Avenatti (attorney for porn star and alleged Donald Trump mistress Stormy Daniels) can run, then, "it opens the door for everyone."

Laugh all you want.

Just remember that Walker this year won a Republican primary for U.S. House and picked up more than 125,000 votes in the general election — winning in Sussex County — against incumbent Congresswoman Lisa Blunt Rochester, who was elected to a second term.

That was after he was accused of being a slumlord by state officials, disowned by the Republican Party and lambasted for his behavior, including screeds against white bread, a video he secretly recorded inside an Alcoholics Anonymous meeting and his repeated claims that Delaware’s elected officials are racist.

"People want a change," he said. "When you go to the grocery store, you want a new product and not the same old thing. There's a demand and a need for someone like me coming out of left field."

Walker, ironically enough, did come out of left field or at least a field of candidates on the left.

He first garnered attention in Delaware in 2016 when he joined a crowded field of six candidates running in the Democratic primary for the U.S. House seat then held by John Carney, who was elected governor that year. Walker finished fifth in that contest, garnering fewer than 3,200 votes.

Largely written off as an also-ran, he stunned the political establishment this year by running as a Republican and knocking off the Delaware GOP's preferred candidate Lee Murphy in the primary before winning nearly 36 percent of the vote in the general election.

The state Republican Party, which disavowed him after the primary, seemed relieved by this latest turn of events.

"I think that is a very interesting decision for him," GOP vice chairwoman Emily Taylor said of Walker's presidential ambitions. "While he made his push as part of the Republican Party, I can say that we're happy to see him leave."

Walker says the feeling is mutual, adding that running as a Republican in Delaware is practically hopeless.

"If you want to win a statewide election here, you have to be a Democrat," he said. "They have more registered voters, they're much better organized and they have a deeper bench. The only way a Republican can win is if they are extraordinarily wealthy or talented as a communicator and a leader and I don't see anyone like that in Delaware."

The Democratic Party in Delaware does not seem any happier he is joining them.

"When Walker ran as Democrat in 2016, he earned less than 5 percent of the vote," said Erik Raser-Schramm, state Democratic Party chairman. "Two years later, he brought his disgraceful brand of racism, misogyny and lunacy to the Republican Party and won their nomination to Congress."

Although he previously backed President Donald Trump, Walker says he does not believe the incumbent is going to win re-election.

"He's overweight and out of shape," he said. "I'm still a conservative but Democrats are going to need a conservative voice in order to win against a conservative like Donald Trump."

If his presidential run does not work out, Walker says he will consider a challenge to either Gov. John Carney or U.S. Sen. Chris Coons — contests in which he believes his blue dog Democrat views will help him.

"The fringe left in Delaware is confined to the higher circles of the party, especially women who enjoy being part of the radical chic," he said. "For most of us life is a struggle and we don't have time for left-wing fantasies. We care about how we're going to pay our rent and how we're going to pay our tuition."

Walker says he's leaning toward a bid for U.S. Senate if his presidential dreams don't pan out. But for now he's focused on the White House.

"There is always a greater-than-zero chance you'll be successful," he said. "That's the American Dream."

Letters to the editor

Editor's note: This article has been updated to remove a letter that claimed to be written by a Delawarean but was actually a form letter submitted to many newspapers under different names. The News Journal is reviewing its policy for confirming the authorship of letters to the editor.

We can save other children, too

As the world held its collective breath, all of the children trapped in a cave in Thailand have been rescued. As a mother of a 5-year-old boy who loves soccer, I can relate to the love the parents feel for these boys. Each of their lives is precious.

Daily, worldwide, more than 15,000 children under the age of 5 die. During three days of the Thai soccer club rescue, over 45,000 children have died who might have lived had the world turned its attention to them as it has to the soccer youth.

These children do not have the light of publicity shining on them. They die because they do not have access to adequate health services, clean water, immunizations, or nutrition.

The U.S., through our USAID programs, addresses many of those issues. Thanks to that work and the work of other nations and nonprofits, the death rate of children under 5 years has dropped more than 50 percent, to 15,000 since 1980. Each of those lives is precious.

Congress has the opportunity to pass the Reach Every Mother and Child Act, which would require that USAID be more effective, focused and accountable for how it spends our current investment in child health. Millions of more lives could be saved at no additional cost to U.S. taxpayers.

I wholeheartedly thank my home state of Delaware’s Sen. Chris Coons for being a champion on the Reach Act and an original co-sponsor, and Rep. Lisa Blunt Rochester for signing onto this legislation. I urge Senator Carper to also help get the Reach Act to a vote in the Senate.

— Aldwyn Hamilton, Washington, D.C.

The news is a day late

For over 50 years, I have been a subscriber to The News Journal. I do not understand why news and sports scores that happen in the previous evening do not make the morning paper.

When I open my paper in the morning, I want to see if my beloved Red Sox won the previous night, not two days later. The same goes for news events that happen in the late evening — they also show up two days later.

"Old news."

Why does the Philadelphia Inquirer have late-night baseball scores and late-breaking evening news from the previous night? Do they make the extra effort to get all the late news and sports scores before they go to print?

— Larry Reverdito, Wilmington

Liberals hypocritical on family separation

Your USA Today editorial on family separation states "Leading experts on child behavior say children could suffer serious physiological damage with each passing day, week or month apart from a parent."

That's probably news to our orphan population that they have physiological damage. Same for children put up for adoption, military children, and children of those incarcerated. What about those working away from home?

It's always hypocritical of Democrats and liberals to find a fight against this administration but never when it involves their sacred services or ideals. Where was the outcry during previous administrations?

— James Gray, Wilmington
